extraExplanation: “Accipiter”是拉丁语，原意接近“鹰/猛禽”。在生物分类学中它是一个“属名”（genus），通常首字母大写并用斜体书写：*Accipiter*。
在日常英语里，人们更常说具体名称（如 “goshawk / sparrowhawk”）或更宽泛的 “hawk”。“accipter”常见为拼写错误，正确拼写是 “accipiter”。

summary.en: Excise can mean a special tax on certain goods, or the act of cutting/removing something.
summary.zh: Excise 既可指对特定商品征收的消费税，也可指切除或删去（某部分内容）。

definition.en: a tax charged on certain goods (such as alcohol, tobacco, or fuel), often collected when they are produced or sold
definition.zh: （对酒、烟、燃油等特定商品征收的）消费税／货物税（通常在生产或销售环节征收）

examples.en: The government raised the excise tax on cigarettes to reduce smoking.
examples.zh: 政府提高了香烟的消费税以减少吸烟。

examples.en: Fuel prices rose after a new excise was introduced.
examples.zh: 新征收燃油消费税后，油价上涨了。

definition.en: to remove or cut out something, especially a part considered harmful or unnecessary
definition.zh: 切除；删去（尤指去除被认为有害或多余的部分）

examples.en: The surgeon excised the tumor completely.
examples.zh: 外科医生将肿瘤完全切除了。

examples.en: The editor excised several sentences to make the article shorter.
examples.zh: 编辑删去了几句话，让文章更简洁。

extraExplanation: 你输入的“accise”通常是拼写错误；标准拼写是“excise”。在新闻和政府文件里最常见的是名词用法“excise tax（消费税）”。
词源提示：excise（切除/删去）来自“切出”的含义，所以在医学（切除肿瘤、组织）和写作编辑（删段落）中也很常用。

summary.en: Accismus is the act of pretending you don’t want something you actually want, often to seem modest or polite.
summary.zh: Accismus 指“明明想要却假装不想要”的推辞姿态，常用来显得谦虚或得体。

definition.en: a rhetorical tactic of pretending not to want something (often praise, power, or a gift) even though you actually do
definition.zh: （修辞）明明想要却装作不想要，假意推辞（常见于称赞、权力或礼物等）

examples.en: When everyone praised her, she used accismus and said, “Oh, I’m really not that good.”
examples.zh: 大家夸她时，她用了“假意推辞”的说法：“哎呀，我哪有那么好。”

examples.en: His accismus about the promotion sounded polite, but he clearly hoped to get it.
examples.zh: 他对升职“假意推辞”听起来很客气，但他显然很想得到。

extraExplanation: accismus 来自古希腊语，常被当作一种“修辞策略/社交礼仪”：表面上拒绝或淡化欲望，以显得谦虚、有分寸，或让对方更强烈地坚持邀请。
在英语文化语境里，它常与“humblebrag（假谦虚炫耀）”“modesty（谦虚）”相关，但 accismus 更强调“想要却装不要”的姿态，而不一定包含炫耀。
文学与修辞讨论中常提到《伊利亚特》里阿基里斯（Achilles）对礼物与和解提议的态度被视为 accismus 的经典例子之一：表面拒绝，实际牵涉更复杂的欲望与立场。

summary.en: “Accite” is an archaic/formal verb meaning “to summon or call someone to come.”
summary.zh: “accite”是一个古义/正式动词，意思是“传唤、召来”。

definition.en: (Archaic or formal) to summon; to call someone to come (often by order or authority).
definition.zh: （古义/正式用语）传唤；召来；命令某人前来（常带有权威或命令意味）。

examples.en: The clerk was sent to accite the witnesses to court.
examples.zh: 书记员被派去传唤证人到法庭。

examples.en: He was accited before the council to answer the charge.
examples.zh: 他被传唤到议会面前回应指控。

extraExplanation: “accite”在现代英语里非常少见，更多出现在旧文献、法律/教会/官方语境中，意思接近“summon”。
学习时要注意它容易和更常见的“excite”（使兴奋）或“incite”（煽动、鼓动）混淆：三者拼写相近，但含义不同。

summary.en: Accius: a well-known Roman tragic poet from the 2nd–1st century BCE, whose works mostly survive only in fragments.
summary.zh: Accius：公元前2—1世纪著名的古罗马悲剧诗人，其作品多仅以残篇流传。

definition.en: A Roman tragic poet (170–c. 86 BCE), famous in antiquity for his powerful Latin tragedies (now mostly surviving only in fragments). Also written as Lucius Accius.
definition.zh: 阿克基乌斯（约公元前170—约前86年），古罗马悲剧诗人；以拉丁悲剧闻名（作品多已失传，仅存残篇）。亦作 Lucius Accius。

examples.en: Accius was one of the major names in early Roman tragedy, even though most of his plays are lost.
examples.zh: 阿克基乌斯是早期罗马悲剧的重要人物之一，尽管他的大部分剧作已经失传。

examples.en: We read a short fragment attributed to Accius in class to see how Latin tragedy sounded.
examples.zh: 课堂上我们读了一段归于阿克基乌斯的残篇，以感受拉丁悲剧的语言风格。

extraExplanation: “Accius”常被提到是因为古代评论家（如西塞罗、昆体良等）引用过他的诗句来谈修辞与文体，因此后世多通过引文来认识他。
古罗马悲剧早期深受希腊悲剧影响，阿克基乌斯被认为文风雄健、语言有力度；但由于文本流失，现代读者通常只能从“残篇（fragments）”间接了解。

summary.en: “Acclaim” means strong public praise (noun) or to praise someone publicly and enthusiastically (verb).
summary.zh: “acclaim”既可作名词表示“广泛的赞誉/好评”，也可作动词表示“公开称赞、热烈喝彩”。

definition.en: public praise or strong approval; enthusiastic recognition from many people
definition.zh: 公众的称赞；高度的认可；广泛的好评

examples.en: The film received critical acclaim and won several awards.
examples.zh: 这部电影获得了影评界的高度好评，并赢得了好几个奖项。

examples.en: Her debut novel brought her international acclaim.
examples.zh: 她的处女作小说为她带来了国际性的赞誉。

definition.en: to praise publicly; to applaud or approve of someone or something enthusiastically
definition.zh: 公开称赞；热烈鼓掌；对某人或某事表示高度赞许

examples.en: The audience acclaimed the singer at the end of the concert.
examples.zh: 演唱会结束时，观众热烈称赞（为）那位歌手鼓掌。

examples.en: Critics acclaimed the director for her bold storytelling.
examples.zh: 评论家称赞这位导演大胆的叙事方式。

extraExplanation: 词源上来自拉丁语前缀 ad-（向、对）+ clamare（呼喊）。原意接近“向……呼喊”，后来发展为“欢呼、喝彩、赞美”。
常见搭配：win/earn/receive acclaim（赢得/获得/得到赞誉）；critical acclaim（评论界好评）；public acclaim（公众赞誉）；acclaim sb. as + 身份（称某人为……），例如：She was acclaimed as a genius.（她被誉为天才。）

summary.en: Acclaimable means worthy of praise or public approval.
summary.zh: Acclaimable 指“值得称赞、值得认可”。

definition.en: deserving praise or approval; worthy of being admired publicly
definition.zh: 值得称赞的；值得公开赞扬或认可的

examples.en: Her calm handling of the crisis was truly acclaimable.
examples.zh: 她在危机中的冷静处理确实值得称赞。

examples.en: The team’s acclaimable efforts improved patient care.
examples.zh: 团队值得称赞的努力改善了病患照护。

extraExplanation: “acclaimable”由动词“acclaim（称赞、喝彩）”加形容词后缀“-able”构成，意思是“能够/值得被称赞”。在现代英语中它不算常用，更常见的替换说法有“praiseworthy”“commendable”“worthy of acclaim”。在正式写作里常用“acclaimed”表示“广受好评的”（强调已经获得称赞），而“acclaimable”强调“值得获得称赞”。

summary.en: Acclaimed describes someone or something widely praised and recognized as excellent.
summary.zh: Acclaimed 用来形容某人或某物“广受赞誉、口碑很好、公认优秀”。

definition.en: praised publicly; recognized by many people as excellent
definition.zh: 广受称赞的；公认优秀的

examples.en: She is an acclaimed actress known for her powerful performances.
examples.zh: 她是一位广受赞誉的女演员，以有感染力的表演闻名。

examples.en: The restaurant is acclaimed for its fresh seafood and warm service.
examples.zh: 这家餐厅因新鲜的海鲜和热情的服务而备受好评。

examples.en: His acclaimed novel was translated into many languages.
examples.zh: 他那本广受赞誉的小说被翻译成多种语言。

extraExplanation: “acclaimed”通常用于正式或书面语，强调“来自大众或权威的公开称赞”。常见搭配：an acclaimed writer/film/album（备受赞誉的作家/电影/专辑），be acclaimed for（因……而受赞扬）。
词源上来自“acclaim”（欢呼、喝彩；称赞）。因此语感上带有“被很多人称赞、口碑很好”的意味。

summary.en: Acclaimedly means “in a way that is widely praised or admired,” but it is uncommon in modern English.
summary.zh: acclaimedly意为“广受赞誉地/备受称赞地”，但在现代英语中不太常用。

definition.en: In a way that receives public praise, approval, or recognition.
definition.zh: 以受到公众称赞、认可或好评的方式；广受赞誉地。

examples.en: Her debut novel was acclaimedly received by critics and readers.
examples.zh: 她的处女作小说受到评论家和读者的广泛好评。

examples.en: The film was acclaimedly described as one of the year’s best.
examples.zh: 这部电影被广泛称赞为年度最佳作品之一。

definition.en: (Less common) In a manner that expresses praise or admiration.
definition.zh: （较少见）以表达称赞或钦佩的方式；赞赏地。

examples.en: The audience spoke acclaimedly of the performer after the show.
examples.zh: 演出结束后，观众对这位表演者赞不绝口。

extraExplanation: “acclaimedly”由形容词“acclaimed（广受赞誉的）”加副词后缀“-ly”构成，但在现代英语里并不常用。更自然的表达通常是：widely acclaimed（广受赞誉）、critically acclaimed（获得影评界好评）、to great acclaim（伴随着热烈赞誉）。
写作中如果想更地道，常用“was widely/critically acclaimed”或“received widespread acclaim”，而不是单独使用“acclaimedly”。

summary.en: An uncommon word meaning a person who publicly praises or applauds.
summary.zh: 不常用词，指公开赞美或鼓掌喝彩的人。

definition.en: a person who acclaims (publicly praises or applauds someone or something)
definition.zh: 喝彩者；称赞者（公开赞美或鼓掌喝彩的人）

examples.en: The singer stepped on stage, and her acclaimer shouted her name from the front row.
examples.zh: 歌手走上舞台时，她的喝彩者在前排大声喊她的名字。

examples.en: In the newspaper article, the mayor had many acclaimers for his quick response.
examples.zh: 在那篇报纸文章里，市长因反应迅速而有许多称赞者。

extraExplanation: “acclaimer”在现代英语中非常少见，更多时候人们会用“admirer”（仰慕者）、“supporter”（支持者）、“fan”（粉丝）来表达类似意思。
很多学习者把“acclaimer”与更常见的“acclaim”（v./n. 赞扬；喝彩）混淆；日常写作里通常用“acclaim”或“praise”更自然。

summary.en: “Acclaimers” means people who publicly praise or applaud someone/something, but the word is uncommon in modern English.
summary.zh: “acclaimers”指公开称赞或为某人/某事喝彩的人，但在现代英语中很少用。

definition.en: a person who praises something or someone publicly; someone who applauds or gives enthusiastic approval
definition.zh: 公开称赞（或喝彩）的人；给予热烈赞同的人

examples.en: The film’s acclaimers cheered loudly at the premiere.
examples.zh: 这部电影的拥护者在首映式上大声欢呼。

examples.en: She became one of the singer’s most loyal acclaimers online.
examples.zh: 她成了这位歌手在网上最忠实的“称赞者”之一。

extraExplanation: “acclaimer”这个词在现代英语里非常少见，通常人们会用“supporter / fan / admirer”来表达“支持者、粉丝、仰慕者”。
你输入的“acclaimers”也可能是把“disclaimers（免责声明）”拼错了：acclaim = 称赞；disclaim = 否认/声明不承担责任，两者意思相反。
“acclaim”更常见的用法是名词或动词：public acclaim（公众赞誉）；to acclaim a winner（为胜者欢呼/喝彩）。

summary.en: “Acclaiming” means giving enthusiastic public praise (and less commonly, publicly proclaiming something).
summary.zh: “acclaiming”表示热烈而公开的称赞（较少见：公开宣布/宣告）。

definition.en: praising someone or something enthusiastically and publicly; expressing strong approval.
definition.zh: 热烈称赞；公开高度赞扬。

examples.en: Critics were acclaiming the film for its powerful story.
examples.zh: 影评人正在热烈称赞这部电影的故事很有力量。

examples.en: Fans stood outside the theater, acclaiming the singer as she arrived.
examples.zh: 粉丝们站在剧院外，在歌手到达时高声称赞她。

definition.en: (less common) announcing something publicly; proclaiming.
definition.zh: （较少见）公开宣布；宣告。

examples.en: The newspaper was acclaiming the discovery as a major breakthrough.
examples.zh: 这家报纸把这项发现公开宣称为一次重大突破。

extraExplanation: “acclaiming”是动词“acclaim”的现在分词/动名词形式，常用于进行时（be acclaiming）或作定语（the acclaiming crowd）。
学习时注意别和“claim（声称）”混淆：acclaim 强调“称赞、喝彩”，带强烈正面情感；claim 只是“提出主张/声称”，不一定褒义。
常见搭配：acclaim someone/something for ...（因……称赞……）；be widely/critically acclaimed（广受/获评论界称赞）。

summary.en: “Acclaims” means public praise (noun plural) or “praises publicly” (verb 3rd-person singular).
summary.zh: “acclaims”可指“赞誉”（名词复数），也可指“公开称赞”（动词第三人称单数）。

definition.en: public praise or enthusiastic approval (plural form of “acclaim”)
definition.zh: 公众的称赞；热烈的赞同（“acclaim”的复数名词）

examples.en: The film opened to widespread acclaims from critics.
examples.zh: 这部电影上映后获得了评论界广泛的称赞。

examples.en: Her debut novel earned international acclaims.
examples.zh: 她的处女作赢得了国际赞誉。

definition.en: praises someone or something publicly; expresses strong approval (third-person singular of “acclaim”)
definition.zh: 公开称赞；高度肯定（动词“acclaim”的第三人称单数）

examples.en: The newspaper acclaims the athlete’s courage.
examples.zh: 这家报纸称赞了这位运动员的勇气。

examples.en: The audience acclaims the performance with loud applause.
examples.zh: 观众以热烈掌声称赞这场演出。

extraExplanation: “acclaim”既可作名词（赞誉），也可作动词（称赞）。写作中更常见的是名词搭配：win/receive/earn acclaim（赢得/获得/得到赞誉）。
拼写提示：acclaim 的名词复数是 acclaims；动词第三人称单数也是 acclaims，需要靠句子结构判断（如主语是单数且后接宾语/介词短语时多为动词）。

summary.en: Acclamation means strong public praise or approval, or a formal decision made unanimously without a vote.
summary.zh: Acclamation 指公众热烈的称赞/赞同，也可指在无人反对时不经投票的一致通过。

definition.en: Loud public praise or approval, often shown by cheering and clapping.
definition.zh: （公众的）热烈称赞或赞同，常以欢呼、鼓掌等方式表现。

examples.en: The singer walked onstage to loud acclamation.
examples.zh: 歌手在热烈的欢呼声中走上舞台。

examples.en: The proposal was met with acclamation from the audience.
examples.zh: 这项提议得到了观众的一致喝彩与赞同。

definition.en: Formal approval given by a group without a vote, because everyone agrees (often: “by acclamation”).
definition.zh: （团体在无人反对时不经投票的）一致通过；口头或鼓掌表决（常用：by acclamation）。

examples.en: She was elected chair by acclamation.
examples.zh: 她在无人反对的情况下当选主席。

examples.en: The motion passed by acclamation.
examples.zh: 该动议在一致赞同下通过。

extraExplanation: “Acclamation”来自拉丁语词根 *clamare*（意为“呼喊”），所以它常带有“群众齐声欢呼”的画面感。
常见搭配：to win/receive/gain acclamation（赢得/获得喝彩）；universal/widespread acclamation（普遍赞誉）；loud/thunderous acclamation（热烈/雷鸣般的欢呼）。
易混词：**acclaim**（名词/动词：赞誉；称赞）更偏“评价/名声”，而 **acclamation** 更强调“现场、公众、齐声”的称赞或一致同意。

summary.en: “Acclamations” means loud, enthusiastic cheers or public praise, often in formal or public contexts.
summary.zh: “acclamations”指热烈的欢呼或公众的称赞，常用于较正式或公开的场合。

definition.en: loud cheers or enthusiastic public praise (the plural of “acclamation”)
definition.zh: 热烈的欢呼；公众的热情称赞（“acclamation”的复数）

examples.en: The singer returned to the stage to loud acclamations.
examples.zh: 歌手在热烈的欢呼声中回到舞台。

examples.en: Her speech was met with acclamations from the crowd.
examples.zh: 她的演讲迎来了人群的热烈称赞。

examples.en: The team received acclamations after the final whistle.
examples.zh: 终场哨响后，球队赢得了阵阵欢呼。

definition.en: formal shouts of approval used to show agreement, welcome, or support in a public setting
definition.zh: （较正式）在公开场合用欢呼表示赞同、欢迎或支持

examples.en: The proposal passed by acclamations in the hall.
examples.zh: 该提案在会场一片赞同声中通过。

examples.en: The new leader was welcomed with acclamations.
examples.zh: 新领导在欢呼声中受到欢迎。

extraExplanation: “acclamation”来自拉丁语 acclamare（对……大声喊叫、喝彩）。它常见于较正式的语境（新闻、演讲、仪式），比 everyday 的“cheers”更书面、更庄重。
相关表达：to win/receive public acclaim（赢得公众赞誉）；critical acclaim（评论界好评）；by acclamation（以鼓掌或欢呼方式一致通过，常指无需正式计票）。

summary.en: An acclamator is someone who cheers or praises loudly, especially as part of a crowd.
summary.zh: acclamator 指“欢呼者/喝彩者”，尤其指在人群中高声表示赞同或赞美的人。

definition.en: a person who acclaims—someone who loudly expresses approval or praise, often as part of a crowd
definition.zh: 欢呼者；喝彩者（大声表达赞同或赞美的人，常见于人群中）

examples.en: The candidate’s speech ended with a wave of acclamators shouting approval.
examples.zh: 候选人的演讲在一片欢呼声中结束，许多喝彩者高声表示支持。

examples.en: In the stadium, acclamators rose to their feet when the team scored.
examples.zh: 在体育场里，球队得分时，欢呼者纷纷起立鼓掌喝彩。

extraExplanation: “acclamator”是较少见的正式用词，多用于书面语或历史/文学语境。日常英语里更常说“cheerer”“supporter”“fan”，或用短语“people who applauded/cheered”。
词源可追溯到拉丁语“acclamare”（大声呼喊、喝彩）。在古罗马或政治集会的描写中，常用类似词指“带头或参与欢呼的人群”。

summary.en: “Acclamatory” means showing enthusiastic public praise or approval.
summary.zh: “acclamatory”指表现出热烈的公开称赞或赞同。

definition.en: expressing strong approval, praise, or enthusiastic support (often in the form of cheering or public applause)
definition.zh: 表示强烈赞同、称赞或热烈支持的（常指欢呼、鼓掌等公开喝彩）

examples.en: The crowd gave an acclamatory cheer when the singer returned to the stage.
examples.zh: 歌手回到舞台时，人群发出了喝彩式的欢呼。

examples.en: Her speech ended with an acclamatory round of applause.
examples.zh: 她的演讲以一阵热烈的掌声收尾。

examples.en: The report took an acclamatory tone, celebrating the team’s success.
examples.zh: 这份报告语气充满赞扬，庆祝团队的成功。

extraExplanation: “acclamatory”来自“acclaim / acclamation（喝彩、称赞）”，词根与拉丁语中表示“呼喊”的含义有关。它多用于较正式的书面语，强调“公开、群体性、热烈”的称赞。

summary.en: Acclimatable means “able to become accustomed to a new environment or climate.”
summary.zh: acclimatable 指“能够逐渐适应新的环境或气候”。

definition.en: Able to become accustomed to a new climate, environment, or situation (often used in science or medicine).
definition.zh: 可适应的；能够逐渐习惯新气候、新环境或新状况的（常用于科学或医学语境）。

examples.en: Some plants are acclimatable to cooler temperatures after a few weeks.
examples.zh: 有些植物在几周后可以适应更低的温度。

examples.en: The researchers tested whether the species is acclimatable to higher altitudes.
examples.zh: 研究人员测试这种物种是否能适应更高海拔。

extraExplanation: 词形提示：acclimatable 来自动词 acclimate（使适应/适应），常见结构是 “be acclimatable to + 环境/条件”。
语用特点：这个词在日常口语里不算常见，更常见的是 say “can acclimate” 或 “can adapt”。在学术写作中用 acclimatable 更显正式、偏科学。
近义词细微差别：adaptable 更泛指“适应能力强”（不一定与气候有关）；acclimatable 更强调对环境/气候等条件的“逐步生理或功能性适应”。

summary.en: Acclimatation means the gradual process of adjusting to a new climate or environment.
summary.zh: acclimatation 指逐渐适应新的气候或环境的过程。

definition.en: The process of gradually getting used to a new climate, environment, or conditions (such as heat, altitude, or a new culture) so your body or behavior can function well.
definition.zh: 逐渐适应新的气候、环境或条件（如高温、高海拔或新文化）的过程，使身体或行为能更好地运作。

examples.en: After a few days of acclimatation to the heat, I stopped feeling so exhausted.
examples.zh: 在适应炎热天气几天后，我就不再那么疲惫了。

examples.en: Proper acclimatation is important when you travel to high altitudes.
examples.zh: 前往高海拔地区时，良好的适应过程很重要。

examples.en: The team planned an extra week for acclimatation before the competition.
examples.zh: 团队在比赛前额外安排了一周用于适应。

extraExplanation: “acclimatation”在英式英语中较常见；美式英语里更常用拼写“acclimatization”。两者意义相同。
常见搭配：acclimatation to + 名词（对……的适应）；例如 acclimatation to the cold / the altitude。
与“adaptation”相比：acclimatation更强调对气候/环境条件的生理或渐进适应；adaptation更广，可指生物进化适应、策略调整，或作品改编（a film adaptation）。

summary.en: Acclimate means to get used to new conditions, or to help someone/something adjust to them.
summary.zh: Acclimate 指（使）逐渐适应新的环境或条件。

definition.en: to become used to a new environment, climate, situation, or level of activity
definition.zh: （使）适应新的环境、气候、情况或活动强度

examples.en: It took me a week to acclimate to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 我花了一周时间才适应高海拔。

examples.en: Give your body time to acclimate after you start exercising again.
examples.zh: 重新开始运动后，给身体一些时间来适应。

examples.en: New employees need time to acclimate to the company culture.
examples.zh: 新员工需要时间来适应公司的文化。

definition.en: to help someone or something adjust to a new environment or conditions
definition.zh: 使（某人/某物）适应新的环境或条件

examples.en: The coach acclimated the team to the heat with shorter practices at first.
examples.zh: 教练一开始用较短的训练让球队逐步适应炎热天气。

examples.en: We acclimated the plants by moving them outside for a few hours each day.
examples.zh: 我们每天把植物搬到室外几个小时，让它们逐步适应。

extraExplanation: “acclimate”常和介词“to”搭配：acclimate to + 环境/条件（例如：acclimate to the cold / to a new job）。
在日常英语里，“acclimatize”也常见（尤其在英式英语中更常用），意思基本相同。

summary.en: “Acclimated” means already used to new conditions; it can also be the past form of “acclimate.”
summary.zh: “acclimated”表示“已适应新的环境/条件”，也可作动词“acclimate”的过去式/过去分词。

definition.en: Adapted or gotten used to a new environment, climate, situation, or routine.
definition.zh: （对新环境、气候、情况或作息）已适应的，已习惯的。

examples.en: After a week in Denver, I finally felt acclimated to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 在丹佛待了一周后，我终于适应了高海拔。

examples.en: It took a few days for the new students to get acclimated to the school schedule.
examples.zh: 新生花了几天才适应学校的作息安排。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of “acclimate”: to help someone or something adapt to a new environment or conditions.
definition.zh: “acclimate”的过去式/过去分词：使（某人/某物）适应新的环境或条件。

examples.en: The hikers acclimated their bodies by spending two nights at a lower camp first.
examples.zh: 徒步者先在较低的营地住了两晚，让身体逐步适应。

examples.en: The zoo acclimated the rescued animal to its new habitat before putting it on display.
examples.zh: 动物园先让获救动物适应新栖息地，再对外展示。

extraExplanation: “acclimated”在日常英语里常作形容词用，表示“已经适应了”。也常与介词搭配：acclimated to + 名词（如：acclimated to the heat/altitude/workload）。
近义表达：adapted to（较通用）、adjusted to（强调心理/习惯上的调整）。
英式拼法有时会见到“acclimatise / acclimatised”。美式更常见“acclimate / acclimated”。

summary.en: Acclimatement means the process of adjusting to a new climate or environment.
summary.zh: Acclimatement 指逐渐适应新的气候或环境的过程。

definition.en: The process of becoming used to a new climate, environment, or situation (such as a different temperature, altitude, or culture).
definition.zh: （对新气候、环境或情境的）适应过程（如温度、海拔或文化的改变）。

examples.en: After moving to Colorado, it took her a few weeks of acclimatement to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 搬到科罗拉多后，她花了几周时间才适应高海拔。

examples.en: The team scheduled extra rest days to support acclimatement to the heat.
examples.zh: 团队安排了额外的休息日，以帮助适应高温。

examples.en: Cultural acclimatement can be just as challenging as physical acclimatement.
examples.zh: 文化适应可能和身体适应一样具有挑战性。

extraExplanation: “acclimatement”常与“acclimatization”互换使用，但在现代英语里“acclimatization”更常见；“acclimatement”也常见于较正式或偏旧的语境。
词根提示：来自“climate（气候）”，前缀“ac-”有“使……、朝向……”的意味；整体表达“让自己变得适应某种气候/环境”。
常见搭配：a period of acclimatement（适应期）；acclimatement to + 名词（对……的适应）；aid/support acclimatement（帮助适应）。

summary.en: “Acclimates” means “(he/she/it) becomes used to” a new environment, or “helps someone/something become used to” it.
summary.zh: “acclimates”表示“（他/她/它）逐渐适应”新环境，或“使（某人/某物）逐渐适应”。

definition.en: to become used to a new climate, environment, or situation over time
definition.zh: （逐渐）适应新的气候、环境或情况

examples.en: After a week in Denver, she acclimated to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 在丹佛待了一周后，她逐渐适应了高海拔。

examples.en: New employees often need time to acclimate to the company culture.
examples.zh: 新员工通常需要时间来适应公司的文化。

definition.en: to help someone or something adjust to a new climate, environment, or condition
definition.zh: 使（某人或某物）适应新的气候、环境或条件

examples.en: The coach acclimated the team to the heat by training outdoors early in the morning.
examples.zh: 教练让球队清晨在户外训练，以帮助他们适应炎热。

examples.en: Hospitals try to acclimate patients to the routine before they go home.
examples.zh: 医院会尽量让病人先适应作息流程再回家。

extraExplanation: “acclimates”是动词“acclimate”的第三人称单数形式（he/she/it acclimates）。常见相关词：acclimation（适应过程/适应期），以及英式更常见的拼写与用法“acclimatise / acclimatize”。
搭配很常见：acclimate to + 名词（acclimate to the weather/altitude/new job）。
语感区分：acclimate更强调“随着时间慢慢适应”（尤其是环境/气候变化）；adapt更广泛，既可指心理/策略上的调整，也可指为了适应而“改造/改变”。

summary.en: “Acclimating” means becoming used to new conditions, or helping someone/something adjust to them.
summary.zh: “acclimating”指逐渐适应新环境/条件，或使某人/某物适应这些变化。

definition.en: becoming used to a new climate, environment, situation, or conditions (such as altitude, temperature, or a new job).
definition.zh: （逐渐）适应新的气候、环境、情境或条件（如海拔、温度或新工作）。

examples.en: It took me about a week to start acclimating to the hot, humid weather.
examples.zh: 我大概花了一周才开始适应又热又潮的天气。

examples.en: After moving to Denver, she spent a few days acclimating to the higher altitude.
examples.zh: 搬到丹佛后，她花了几天适应更高的海拔。

examples.en: He’s still acclimating to the pace of his new workplace.
examples.zh: 他还在适应新工作环境的节奏。

definition.en: helping someone or something become used to a new climate or environment; making adjustments so they can function well.
definition.zh: 使（人或事物）适应新的气候或环境；通过调整让其更好地运行/生存。

examples.en: The coach is acclimating the team to training in colder conditions.
examples.zh: 教练正在让球队适应更寒冷条件下的训练。

examples.en: The zoo is acclimating the rescued animals before releasing them into a larger habitat.
examples.zh: 动物园在把获救动物放入更大栖息地前，先让它们适应环境。

extraExplanation: “acclimating”来自动词 acclimate（适应）。日常英语里，它常和 to 连用：acclimate/acclimating to + 名词（conditions / altitude / heat / a new routine）。
在科学或正式语境中，你也会看到 acclimatize（英式拼法/变体），意思非常接近；美式日常写作更常用 acclimate。

summary.en: Acclimation is the process of gradually adjusting to new conditions, especially a new climate or environment.
summary.zh: Acclimation 指逐渐适应新条件的过程，尤指新的气候或环境。

definition.en: The process of becoming used to a new environment or conditions (such as a new climate, altitude, workplace, or culture).
definition.zh: （对新环境或新条件的）适应过程；逐渐习惯（如新气候、高海拔、工作环境或文化）。

examples.en: It took her a few days of acclimation to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 她花了几天时间才适应高海拔环境。

examples.en: During the first week, give yourself time for acclimation to the new job schedule.
examples.zh: 第一周先给自己一些时间适应新的工作作息。

extraExplanation: “acclimation”和“acclimatization”都表示“适应”，日常英语里常可互换；在更严格的用法中，acclimation 常指在人工或受控环境中的适应（如实验室、训练），acclimatization 更常指对自然环境变化的适应（如季节变化、迁居到另一气候带）。
常见搭配：acclimation to + 名词（acclimation to the heat/altitude/new routine）。也常与动词连用：need time for acclimation（需要适应时间）。

summary.en: “Acclimations” means the processes or periods of adapting to new conditions (plural of “acclimation”).
summary.zh: “acclimations”指对新环境/条件的适应过程（“acclimation”的复数）。

definition.en: the process of getting used to a new climate, environment, or situation; the changes that help you adapt
definition.zh: （对新气候、环境或情况的）适应过程；适应性变化

examples.en: It takes time for new students to go through acclimation to college life.
examples.zh: 新生适应大学生活需要一段时间。

examples.en: Athletes often arrive early to allow acclimation to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 运动员常常提前到达，以便适应高海拔环境。

examples.en: After a few weeks of acclimation, the cold weather felt less harsh.
examples.zh: 适应了几周之后，寒冷的天气感觉没那么难熬了。

extraExplanation: “acclimations”是名词复数，单数是“acclimation”。在美式英语中更常见的近义词是“acclimatization”（更偏正式/科学语境）。
注意不要和“acclamations”（欢呼、喝彩）混淆：acclimation=适应；acclamation=喝彩。

summary.en: “Acclimatisable” means capable of adapting to new climates or conditions.
summary.zh: “acclimatisable”指能够逐渐适应新的气候或环境条件。

definition.en: Able to become used to a new climate, environment, or conditions over time.
definition.zh: 能够逐渐适应新的气候、环境或条件的。

examples.en: Some plants are highly acclimatisable and can survive in both cool and warm regions.
examples.zh: 有些植物很适应环境，既能在凉爽地区也能在温暖地区生存。

examples.en: With training, people can become acclimatisable to high altitude and thinner air.
examples.zh: 通过训练，人可以逐步适应高海拔和更稀薄的空气。

extraExplanation: “acclimatisable”是英式拼写；美式常见拼写为“acclimatizable”。两者意思相同。
构词上：acclimatise（使适应）+ -able（可……的），强调“有能力适应/可被适应化”。在科学、医学、生态学语境中较常见。
在日常英语里更常用的表达通常是“adaptable”（适应能力强的）或“able to acclimatize”。

summary.en: Acclimatisation means the gradual process of adapting to a new climate or conditions, especially high altitude.
summary.zh: acclimatisation 指逐渐适应新的气候或环境条件的过程，尤指高海拔环境。

definition.en: The process of gradually becoming used to a new climate, environment, or conditions (such as altitude or temperature).
definition.zh: （对新气候、环境或条件如高海拔、温度等的）逐渐适应过程。

examples.en: During the first week in the mountains, we focused on acclimatisation to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 在山里的第一周，我们主要专注于适应高海拔。

examples.en: Good acclimatisation can reduce the risk of altitude sickness.
examples.zh: 良好的适应过程可以降低高原反应的风险。

examples.en: The athletes arrived early to allow time for acclimatisation before the competition.
examples.zh: 运动员提前到达，以便在比赛前留出适应时间。

extraExplanation: “acclimatisation”是英式拼写；美式更常写作“acclimatization”。两者意思相同。
在登山与高海拔旅行语境中很常见：通常指循序渐进上升、补水与休息，让身体适应低氧环境。

summary.en: Acclimatise means to (help someone or something) gradually get used to a new climate or environment.
summary.zh: Acclimatise 指（使）逐渐适应新的气候或环境。

definition.en: to become used to a new climate, place, or situation (especially a new temperature, altitude, or environment)
definition.zh: （尤指对新的温度、海拔或环境）逐渐适应新的气候、地点或情况

examples.en: It took her a week to acclimatise to the heat.
examples.zh: 她花了一周时间才适应炎热的天气。

examples.en: Give your body time to acclimatise before hiking at high altitude.
examples.zh: 在高海拔徒步前，要给身体时间去适应。

examples.en: New students often acclimatise faster when they join clubs and talk to classmates.
examples.zh: 新生参加社团、和同学多交流，往往适应得更快。

definition.en: to help someone or something become used to a new climate or environment
definition.zh: 使（某人或某物）适应新的气候或环境

examples.en: The zookeepers acclimatised the rescued animals to their new habitat.
examples.zh: 动物园饲养员让获救的动物逐渐适应新栖息地。

examples.en: The company runs a short program to acclimatise new staff to the workplace culture.
examples.zh: 公司会安排一个短期项目，帮助新员工适应职场文化。

extraExplanation: “acclimatise”是英式拼写；美式更常写作“acclimatize”，意思相同。
常与介词“to”搭配：acclimatise to (the heat / the cold / high altitude / a new city)。
与“adapt”相比，“acclimatise”更强调身体或生活节奏“逐渐习惯”环境变化，尤其是气候、温度、海拔等因素。

summary.en: “Acclimatised” means adapted or gotten used to a new climate, environment, or situation (BrE spelling).
summary.zh: “acclimatised”表示已适应或已习惯新的气候、环境或情况（英式拼写）。

definition.en: (BrE spelling) Having become used to a new climate, environment, or situation; adapted.
definition.zh: （英式拼写）已经适应了新的气候、环境或情况；已习惯。

examples.en: After two weeks in Mexico City, I finally felt acclimatised to the altitude.
examples.zh: 在墨西哥城待了两周后，我终于适应了那里的高海拔。

examples.en: It took her a month to get acclimatised to her new job.
examples.zh: 她花了一个月才适应新工作。

definition.en: (BrE spelling of the past tense/past participle of “acclimatise”) To become used to a new climate, environment, or situation; to adapt.
definition.zh: （英式拼写，“acclimatise”的过去式/过去分词）适应（新的气候、环境或情况）；习惯。

examples.en: The plants acclimatised quickly after being moved into the greenhouse.
examples.zh: 这些植物搬进温室后很快就适应了。

examples.en: By the end of the semester, he had acclimatised to studying in English.
examples.zh: 到学期末，他已经适应了用英语学习。

extraExplanation: “acclimatised”主要是英式拼写；美式更常写作“acclimatized”。两者意思相同。
常见搭配：acclimatised to + 名词（acclimatised to the heat/altitude/new routine）。
在旅游、搬家、换工作/学校、以及生物适应环境的语境中非常常见。

summary.en: “Acclimatiser” means a person or device that helps someone or something adjust to a new environment; it is the British spelling of “acclimatizer.”
summary.zh: “acclimatiser”指帮助人或事物适应新环境的人员或装置；是“acclimatizer”的英式拼写。

definition.en: a person, thing, or device that helps someone or something become used to a new climate, environment, or conditions (British spelling; also written as “acclimatizer”).
definition.zh: 使（人或事物）适应新气候/新环境/新条件的人、事物或装置（英式拼写；也可写作“acclimatizer”）。

examples.en: An acclimatiser can help travelers adjust to high altitude more safely.
examples.zh: 适应器/适应辅助措施可以帮助旅行者更安全地适应高海拔环境。

examples.en: In some labs, special acclimatisers control temperature and humidity to help animals adjust gradually.
examples.zh: 在一些实验室里，会用特殊的环境调节装置控制温度和湿度，让动物逐步适应。

extraExplanation: “acclimatiser”是较不常见的名词形式，来自动词“acclimatise”（英式拼写；美式多写作“acclimatize”）。在美式英语中，更常见的对应名词是“acclimatizer”，而在日常表达里也常直接说“something that helps you acclimatize”（帮助你适应的东西）。

summary.en: Acclimatising means getting used to new conditions, or helping someone/something adapt to them.
summary.zh: Acclimatising 指逐渐适应新环境/条件，或使他人/动植物适应新条件。

definition.en: adjusting yourself to a new climate, environment, or conditions (such as altitude or a new workplace routine).
definition.zh: （使自己）适应新的气候、环境或条件（如高海拔或新的工作作息）。

examples.en: It took me a week to start acclimatising to the heat.
examples.zh: 我花了一周才开始适应炎热的天气。

examples.en: She’s still acclimatising to life in a new country.
examples.zh: 她仍在适应在新国家的生活。

definition.en: helping a person, animal, or plant become used to new conditions.
definition.zh: （使他人/动物/植物）适应新的条件。

examples.en: The staff are acclimatising the rescued birds to outdoor temperatures.
examples.zh: 工作人员正在让获救的鸟逐渐适应户外温度。

examples.en: They are acclimatising the plants before moving them into the garden.
examples.zh: 他们在把植物移到花园前，先让它们逐步适应环境。

extraExplanation: “acclimatising”是英式拼写；美式更常写作“acclimatizing”。含义相同。
常见搭配：acclimatise to + 名词/动名词（acclimatise to the heat / to living at high altitude）。
在高海拔语境里，acclimatising 常指身体逐渐适应较低氧气环境；旅行建议通常会强调“give yourself time to acclimatise”。

summary.en: “Acclimatizable” means able to adapt to a new climate or environment.
summary.zh: “acclimatizable”指能够适应新的气候或环境。

definition.en: Able to become accustomed to a new climate, environment, or situation; capable of being acclimatized.
definition.zh: 可适应新气候/新环境/新情况的；能够被驯化（适应）的。

examples.en: Some plants are acclimatizable and can survive after being moved to a colder region.
examples.zh: 有些植物很可适应环境，移到更寒冷的地区后也能存活。

examples.en: The researchers chose an acclimatizable species for the reintroduction program.
examples.zh: 研究人员为重新引入计划选择了一种适应性强、可适应环境的物种。

extraExplanation: “acclimatizable”由“acclimatize（使适应/适应新环境）+ -able（能够……的）”构成，常见于较正式的写作（如生物学、生态学、医学或环境研究）。日常口语里更常用“adaptable（适应性强的）”或直接说“can acclimate（能适应）”。

summary.en: Acclimatization is the gradual process of getting used to a new climate or environment, especially heat, cold, or high altitude.
summary.zh: Acclimatization 指逐步适应新的气候或环境的过程，尤其常见于适应高温、寒冷或高海拔。

definition.en: The process of becoming used to a new climate, environment, altitude, or conditions over time.
definition.zh: （逐渐）适应新的气候、环境、海拔或条件的过程。

examples.en: It takes a few days of acclimatization before you feel comfortable at high altitude.
examples.zh: 在高海拔地区，通常需要几天的适应期才会感觉舒服。

examples.en: The doctor advised slow acclimatization to the heat to avoid heat exhaustion.
examples.zh: 医生建议慢慢适应高温，以避免中暑或热衰竭。

definition.en: In biology, the adjustment of an organism to new environmental conditions (for example, changes in temperature or light).
definition.zh: （生物学）生物体对新环境条件（如温度、光照变化）的调节与适应。

examples.en: Acclimatization helps some plants survive when moved to a cooler region.
examples.zh: 适应过程能帮助某些植物在被移到更冷的地区后存活。

examples.en: Researchers studied the acclimatization of fish to warmer water.
examples.zh: 研究人员研究了鱼类对更温暖水温的适应。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：acclimatization 来自 a-（表示“使……成为”）+ climate（气候）+ -ization（名词后缀，表示“过程/结果”），强调“逐步适应”的过程。
易混辨析：acclimatization 常用于“气候/海拔/自然条件”的适应；adaptation（适应）范围更广，也可指长期的进化适应。
常见搭配：acclimatization period（适应期）、gradual acclimatization（逐步适应）、acclimatization to altitude/heat/cold（适应海拔/高温/寒冷）。

summary.en: “Acclimatizations” means multiple processes of adjusting to a new climate or environment.
summary.zh: “acclimatizations”指多个“适应新气候或新环境的过程”。

definition.en: The process(es) of becoming used to a new climate, environment, or conditions (plural of “acclimatization”).
definition.zh: （acclimatization 的复数）适应（过程）：逐渐习惯新的气候、环境或条件的过程。

examples.en: High-altitude acclimatizations can take days or even weeks.
examples.zh: 高海拔的适应过程可能需要几天甚至几周。

examples.en: The researchers tracked the animals’ acclimatizations to colder water.
examples.zh: 研究人员追踪了这些动物对更冷水温的适应过程。

extraExplanation: “acclimatization”常用于生理或生态语境（如高海拔、温度变化），强调“逐渐适应”的过程。日常英语里也常用更短的“acclimation”（意思相近），尤其在美式英语中更常见。
词形提示：单数是 acclimatization；复数是 acclimatizations（在学术写作中用来指“多次/多种适应过程”或“不同对象的适应过程”）。

summary.en: Acclimatize means to (become) get used to a new climate or environment, or to help someone/something adjust.
summary.zh: Acclimatize 指（逐渐）适应新的气候或环境，也可指使某人/某物适应。

definition.en: to become used to a new climate, environment, or situation over time
definition.zh: （逐渐）适应新的气候、环境或处境

examples.en: It took her a few weeks to acclimatize to the dry weather.
examples.zh: 她花了几周时间才适应干燥的天气。

examples.en: New students often need time to acclimatize to a different school culture.
examples.zh: 新生通常需要时间适应不同的校园文化。

examples.en: If you’re traveling to high altitude, acclimatize slowly to avoid altitude sickness.
examples.zh: 如果你要去高海拔地区，最好慢慢适应，以避免高原反应。

definition.en: to help someone or something become used to a new climate or environment
definition.zh: 使（某人或某物）适应新的气候或环境

examples.en: The trainers acclimatized the team to the heat by practicing earlier each day.
examples.zh: 教练让球队每天更早训练，以帮助他们适应炎热。

examples.en: The zoo acclimatizes rescued animals before releasing them into the wild.
examples.zh: 动物园会先让被救助的动物适应环境，然后再放归野外。

extraExplanation: 英式拼写常见为 acclimatise；美式拼写多用 acclimatize。
常与 to 连用（acclimatize to...），也可与人称搭配（acclimatize yourself to...）。
在健康与旅行语境中，acclimatize 常指对“高海拔/高温/高湿”等环境的生理适应。

summary.en: gradually become used to a new environment or situation
summary.zh: 逐渐适应新的环境或处境

definition.en: to gradually get used to a new climate, environment, situation, or way of life
definition.zh: 逐渐适应新的气候、环境、处境或生活方式

examples.en: It took me a few weeks to acclimatize myself to the cold winter.
examples.zh: 我花了几周才让自己适应寒冷的冬天。

examples.en: New employees need time to acclimatize themselves to the company culture.
examples.zh: 新员工需要时间让自己适应公司的文化。

examples.en: When you move abroad, try to acclimatize yourself to local customs step by step.
examples.zh: 搬到国外后，尽量一步步让自己适应当地习俗。

extraExplanation: 常见搭配：acclimatize oneself to + 名词（the weather / the altitude / a new routine / local food / life in a new city）。
语感上强调“逐渐适应”的过程（需要时间）。如果想表达“已经完全适应”，常用：be/get used to。
拼写差异：美式常见 acclimatize，英式也常见 acclimatise；意义相同。
etymology: 来自“acclimatize”（使适应气候/环境），词根与“climate（气候）”相关；后来含义扩展为对更广泛的“新环境、新规则”的适应。“oneself”表示“让自己（逐渐）适应”。
mnemonic: 把它拆开记：ac- + climate（气候）+ -ize（使…化）→ “使自己进入某种气候/环境状态”＝适应。
联想中文“入乡随俗”：到新地方要慢慢“调气候、调作息”，就是 acclimatize oneself to。

summary.en: “Acclimatized” means having become used to a new climate or situation; it can also be the past form of “acclimatize.”
summary.zh: “acclimatized”表示已适应新的气候或环境；也可作“acclimatize”的过去式/过去分词。

definition.en: Adjusted to a new climate, environment, or situation after a period of getting used to it.
definition.zh: （在一段适应期后）已适应新的气候、环境或情况的。

examples.en: After a few weeks in Denver, I felt acclimatized to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 在丹佛待了几周后，我感觉自己已经适应了高海拔。

examples.en: It takes time to become acclimatized to a new job and workplace culture.
examples.zh: 适应一份新工作和职场文化需要时间。

definition.en: Became adjusted to a new climate, environment, or situation (past form of “acclimatize”).
definition.zh: （acclimatize 的过去式/过去分词）使……适应；（自己）适应。

examples.en: The hikers acclimatized by spending two nights at a lower camp.
examples.zh: 徒步者在较低的营地住了两晚来进行适应。

examples.en: The animals were acclimatized before being released into the reserve.
examples.zh: 这些动物在被放归保护区之前已经完成了适应训练/过程。

extraExplanation: “acclimatized”既常作形容词（已适应的），也可看作动词“acclimatize”的过去式/过去分词。日常表达里形容词用法很常见：be/feel acclimatized to…（已适应……）。
常见搭配：acclimatized to the heat/cold/altitude（适应炎热/寒冷/海拔）；fully/well acclimatized（完全/很好地适应）。在登山与高原旅行语境中尤其常用。
拼写提示：美式英语常用 acclimatize；英式英语也常见 acclimatise。两者意思相同。

summary.en: An acclimatizer is something or someone that helps with acclimatizing—getting used to a new climate or environment.
summary.zh: acclimatizer 指帮助适应新气候或新环境的事物或人。

definition.en: A person, device, or organism that helps someone or something become used to a new climate or environment (such as different temperature, altitude, or conditions).
definition.zh: 使（人、物或生物）适应新气候或新环境的人、装置或生物（如不同温度、海拔或条件）。

examples.en: The training program acted as an acclimatizer, helping new hikers adjust to high altitude.
examples.zh: 这套训练计划起到了适应器的作用，帮助新徒步者适应高海拔。

examples.en: In the greenhouse, the misting system is an acclimatizer for young plants before they are moved outdoors.
examples.zh: 在温室里，喷雾系统是幼苗移到室外前的“适应器”。

extraExplanation: “acclimatizer”并不是日常英语里的高频词，更常见的表达是动词和名词：acclimatize（适应）、acclimatization（适应过程）。在科技/园艺/训练语境里，才可能把某个系统或方案比喻成“acclimatizer”。
词根提示：climate（气候）→ acclimatize（使适应气候/环境）→ acclimatizer（使之适应的东西/人）。
如果你想表达“让人更快适应”的事物，更自然的替代说法包括：a tool that helps people acclimatize / an acclimation program / a system for acclimatization。

summary.en: “Acclimatizes” means “adapts or helps someone/something adapt gradually,” especially to a new climate or environment (present tense, third-person singular of acclimatize).
summary.zh: “acclimatizes”意为“（逐渐）适应/使适应”，常指对新气候或新环境的适应；是acclimatize的第三人称单数现在时。

definition.en: to become used to a new climate, environment, or situation; to adapt gradually
definition.zh: （逐渐）适应新的气候、环境或情况

examples.en: After a week in the mountains, she acclimatized to the thin air.
examples.zh: 在山里待了一周后，她逐渐适应了稀薄的空气。

examples.en: It takes time for your body to acclimatize to the heat.
examples.zh: 你的身体需要时间来适应炎热。

definition.en: to help a person, animal, or plant become used to a new climate or environment
definition.zh: 使（人/动物/植物）适应新的气候或环境

examples.en: The zookeepers acclimatized the rescued animals before releasing them.
examples.zh: 饲养员先让获救的动物适应环境，再放归自然。

examples.en: Farmers acclimatize young plants to outdoor sunlight by moving them outside little by little.
examples.zh: 农民通过逐步把幼苗搬到室外，让它们适应户外阳光。

extraExplanation: “acclimatize”在美式英语中更常见；英式拼写常见为“acclimatise”。两者意思相同。
词根与“climate（气候）”相关，常用于健康/旅行（适应高海拔、炎热）、生物学与园艺（动植物适应新环境）等语境。
常见搭配：acclimatize to + 名词（acclimatize to the altitude/heat/new routine）。

summary.en: Acclimatizing means gradually getting used to a new climate or environment, or helping someone/something adjust to it.
summary.zh: Acclimatizing 指逐渐适应新的气候或环境，也可指使他人或动植物适应新环境。

definition.en: becoming used to a new climate, environment, or situation over time
definition.zh: 逐渐适应新的气候、环境或情况

examples.en: It took me a few days of acclimatizing before I could sleep well at high altitude.
examples.zh: 在高海拔地区，我花了几天适应后才睡得好。

examples.en: After moving to a colder city, she spent the first week acclimatizing to the weather.
examples.zh: 搬到更冷的城市后，她第一周都在适应那里的天气。

definition.en: helping someone or something adjust to a new climate or environment
definition.zh: 使（人或动植物等）适应新的气候或环境

examples.en: The zookeepers are acclimatizing the animals to their new enclosure.
examples.zh: 动物园饲养员正在让动物适应新的围栏环境。

examples.en: The coach started light training to acclimatize the team to the heat.
examples.zh: 教练从轻度训练开始，让球队适应高温。

extraExplanation: “acclimatizing”是动词“acclimatize”的现在分词/动名词形式，常用于旅行、搬家、登山（尤其高海拔）、以及生物学/生态学语境。
拼写与用法提示：美式常见“acclimatize”，也常用更短的“acclimate”；英式对应“acclimatise”。意思基本相同。

summary.en: An uncommon noun meaning something or someone that helps with acclimating to new conditions.
summary.zh: 一个较少见的名词，指帮助适应新环境/条件的人、事物或装置。

definition.en: a person, thing, or device that helps someone or something become used to a new climate, environment, or conditions (rare).
definition.zh: 帮助人或事物适应新的气候、环境或条件的人/事物/装置（较少用）。

examples.en: The greenhouse uses a small acclimator to prepare young plants for outdoor temperatures.
examples.zh: 这座温室用一个小型“适应装置”来让幼苗逐步适应户外温度。

examples.en: For high-altitude trips, a good guide can act as an acclimator by planning slow, safe climbs.
examples.zh: 在高海拔旅行中，一个好的向导可以通过安排缓慢、安全的攀登来起到“适应引导者”的作用。

extraExplanation: “acclimator”在现代英语里不算常见；更常见的是动词 acclimate（使适应/适应）或名词 acclimation（适应过程）。在科技或园艺语境中，acclimator 有时可指“用于让设备/生物逐步适应新条件的装置/系统”。
拼写提示：acclimator 来自 acclimate + -or（表示“做某事的人/物”）。英式英语中也常见相关词 acclimatise / acclimatisation。

summary.en: A rare word meaning “acclimatization,” the process of adapting to new conditions.
summary.zh: 一个罕用词，意为“acclimatization（适应过程）”，指适应新环境/条件的过程。

definition.en: (Rare) The process of becoming used to a new climate, environment, or conditions; acclimatization.
definition.zh: （罕用）适应新气候、环境或条件的过程；驯化；适应（= acclimatization）。

examples.en: After moving to Denver, her acclimature to the high altitude took a few weeks.
examples.zh: 搬到丹佛后，她对高海拔的适应（acclimature）花了几周时间。

examples.en: Good sleep and hydration can support acclimature in a hotter climate.
examples.zh: 充足睡眠和补水能帮助人在更炎热的气候中更好地适应（acclimature）。

extraExplanation: “acclimature”在现代英语中非常少见，很多时候会被认为是拼写错误或非常不标准的用法。更常见、更自然的表达是：名词用“acclimatization”，动词用“acclimate”（美式更常见）或“acclimatize”（英式更常见）。
构词上它来自“acclimate/acclimatize”（使适应），有时在旧文本或特定领域里会把过程名词写成“acclimature”，但日常写作与考试中建议避免。

summary.en: Acclinal means “sloping upward,” used mainly in geology for strata that dip up into a slope (often similar to anaclinal).
summary.zh: acclinal 指“向上倾斜的”，多用于地质学，描述地层向坡内上倾（常与 anaclinal 用法相近）。

definition.en: (Geology, rare) Sloping upward; especially describing rock layers (strata) that dip upward relative to the land surface (often used similarly to “anaclinal”).
definition.zh: （地质学，较少见）向上倾斜的；尤指岩层（地层）的倾向与地表坡向相对，呈“向上倾”的状态（常与 anaclinal 用法相近）。

examples.en: On an acclinal slope, the strata dip into the hill rather than out of it.
examples.zh: 在 acclinal（向上倾）坡面上，地层是向山体内部倾斜，而不是向外倾斜。

examples.en: The map shows an acclinal arrangement of beds, which can reduce the chance of rockslides compared with a dip slope.
examples.zh: 地图显示地层呈 acclinal（向上倾）排列，相比顺倾坡（dip slope），可能更不易发生岩体滑动。

extraExplanation: 这个词在现代英语里很少见，主要出现在地貌/构造地质的专业描述中。学习时可以把它和两个更常见的术语一起记：cataclinal（顺倾：地层倾向与坡向一致）与 anaclinal（逆倾：地层倾向与坡向相反）。在一些资料里 acclinal 会被当作 anaclinal 的近义或较旧的说法，具体以作者定义为准。

summary.en: Acclinate means to adjust (or become adjusted) to a new climate or environment, but it is rare; acclimate/acclimatize are more common.
summary.zh: acclinate 表示（使）适应新气候或环境，但较少用；更常用的是 acclimate / acclimatize。

definition.en: To help a person, animal, or plant adjust to a new climate, environment, or conditions; to acclimate.
definition.zh: 使（人/动物/植物）适应新的气候、环境或条件；使习惯（同 acclimate）。

examples.en: It can take a few days to acclinate to the high altitude.
examples.zh: 适应高海拔可能需要几天时间。

examples.en: The zoo tries to acclinate rescued animals before releasing them.
examples.zh: 动物园会先让获救动物适应环境，再进行放归。

definition.en: To become used to a new climate or situation over time.
definition.zh: 逐渐适应新的气候或处境。

examples.en: New students usually acclinate quickly to the campus routine.
examples.zh: 新生通常很快就能适应校园作息。

extraExplanation: “acclinate”在现代英语里比较少见，很多情况下会被认为是不标准或拼写不常用的形式。更常见、更推荐的词是“acclimate”（美式更常用）或“acclimatize”（英式更常见）。
如果你在写作或考试中使用，建议改用“acclimate / acclimatize”，表达更自然、也更容易被读者接受。

summary.en: Acclivities are upward slopes (the plural of *acclivity*).
summary.zh: acclivities 指“上坡、上升的斜坡”，是 acclivity 的复数。

definition.en: Upward slopes or rising sides of hills, roads, or land (plural of *acclivity*).
definition.zh: 上坡；上升的斜坡（*acclivity* 的复数）。

examples.en: The cyclists struggled on the acclivities leading up to the mountain pass.
examples.zh: 骑行者在通往山口的上坡路段上十分吃力。

examples.en: Houses were built on the acclivities above the river.
examples.zh: 房子建在河流上方的坡地上。

extraExplanation: “acclivity”比较少见，日常更常用的说法是 *uphill*（上坡）或 *upward slope*（上升的斜坡）。
很多学习者会把 *acclivity* 和 *proclivity* 混淆：*acclivity* 是“地形上的上坡”，而 *proclivity* 是“（性格/习惯上的）倾向、癖好”。两者长得像，但意思完全不同。
词根提示：*acclivity* 来自拉丁语 *clivus*（斜坡）。同根词还有 *declivity*（下坡、下斜）。

summary.en: Acclivitous means “sloping upward” or “going uphill.”
summary.zh: acclivitous 意为“向上倾斜的、上坡的”。

definition.en: sloping upward; rising; going up a hill.
definition.zh: 向上倾斜的；上坡的；逐渐升高的。

examples.en: The trail becomes acclivitous after the bridge, so take smaller steps.
examples.zh: 过桥后小路变得上坡了，所以步子放小一点。

examples.en: We chose an acclivitous route to reach the lookout point faster.
examples.zh: 我们选了一条上坡路线，好更快到达观景点。

examples.en: The road is gentle at first but turns acclivitous near the village.
examples.zh: 这条路起初很平缓，但靠近村庄时变成上坡。

extraExplanation: 词源：来自拉丁语 *acclivis*（向上倾斜的），由 *ad-*（向）+ *clivus*（坡）构成。常见搭配有 *acclivitous slope/road/path*。
用法提示：*acclivitous* 比较书面、少见；日常英语更常说 *uphill*, *ascending*, *rising*。它的反义词常见为 *declivitous*（向下倾斜的，较少见）或更常用的 *downhill*。

summary.en: Acclivity means an upward slope; more rarely, it can mean a tendency toward something.
summary.zh: Acclivity 指“上坡/向上的斜坡”；较少见的用法是指“倾向”。

definition.en: an upward slope; a piece of ground that rises
definition.zh: 上坡；向上的斜坡；上升的坡地

examples.en: The road becomes a steep acclivity after the bridge.
examples.zh: 过桥后，这条路变成了很陡的上坡。

examples.en: They rested halfway up the acclivity to catch their breath.
examples.zh: 他们在上坡走到一半时停下来喘口气。

definition.en: a tendency or inclination to do something (less common)
definition.zh: （较少用）倾向；癖好；爱好

examples.en: She has an acclivity toward careful planning before she acts.
examples.zh: 她在行动前有先仔细规划的倾向。

extraExplanation: “acclivity”常见于较正式或文学性的语境，日常英语里更常用“uphill slope / incline”。
词源上来自拉丁语，含义与“climb（攀爬）”同源，因此容易联想到“向上”。
易混淆词：acclivity（上坡） vs. declivity（下坡）。写作时可以用“ac-（向上）/ de-（向下）”帮助记忆。

summary.en: Acclivous means “sloping upward” or “uphill.”
summary.zh: acclivous 意为“向上倾斜的、上坡的”。

definition.en: Sloping upward; rising (especially of a surface, road, or hillside).
definition.zh: 向上倾斜的；上坡的（尤指地面、道路或山坡）。

examples.en: The hikers struggled up an acclivous trail.
examples.zh: 徒步者在一条上坡的小径上艰难前行。

examples.en: An acclivous road can be dangerous when it’s icy.
examples.zh: 结冰时，上坡路可能很危险。

extraExplanation: “acclivous”较为书面、少见，常见替代词有“uphill”“ascending”“upward-sloping”。
词源来自拉丁语：ad-（向、朝）+ clivus（坡），字面意思就是“朝向坡面/上坡”。
对应的反义词是“declivous”（向下倾斜的、下坡的），但同样偏书面。

summary.en: Accloy means to make something or someone feel unpleasantly over-satisfied—often because it’s too sweet, rich, or excessive.
summary.zh: Accloy 指因过甜、过浓或过度而让人“腻”、过饱或反感。

definition.en: to make something cloying (too sweet, rich, or sentimental), so it becomes unpleasant; to satiate or disgust by excess
definition.zh: 使……变得甜腻/腻人（过甜、过浓或过于煽情以致令人不适）；因过度而使人厌腻/倒胃口

examples.en: The dessert was fine at first, but too much syrup accloyed it.
examples.zh: 这份甜点一开始还不错，但糖浆放太多就变得甜腻了。

examples.en: Endless compliments can accloy even a confident person.
examples.zh: 无休止的夸奖即使对自信的人也会让人厌腻。

examples.en: The novel’s constant tragedy begins to accloy after a while.
examples.zh: 这部小说持续不断的悲情描写，读久了会让人有些腻。

extraExplanation: “accloy”比较少见、偏文学用法，意思接近“使人发腻/倒胃口”。常见替代说法有：make (someone) sick of, cloy, satiate, overwhelm。
词形上可理解为 a-（加强/使……）+ cloy（使发腻）。与“cloying（甜腻的、腻人的）”同根。

summary.en: Accost means to approach and speak to someone in a bold, intrusive, or confrontational way (often to stop them).
summary.zh: Accost 指唐突地上前拦住并搭话/质问某人，常带冒犯或对立语气。

definition.en: (Commonly spelled **accost**) To approach someone boldly or aggressively and speak to them, often in a way that feels intrusive or confrontational.
definition.zh: （常见拼写为 **accost**）上前搭话、拦住并与某人说话，常带有唐突、冒犯或对质的感觉。

examples.en: A stranger accosted me on the subway and demanded money.
examples.zh: 地铁上一个陌生人突然拦住我，要求给他钱。

examples.en: Reporters accosted the actor outside the hotel.
examples.zh: 记者在酒店外围住那位演员追问。

examples.en: She felt uncomfortable when he accosted her in the parking lot.
examples.zh: 他在停车场突然上前搭话，让她感到不舒服。

extraExplanation: 你输入的 **accoast** 很可能是拼写错误，正确拼写通常是 **accost**（拦住并搭话/质问）。
**accost** 语气往往偏负面：不是普通的“上前打招呼”（say hi / greet），而是带有“突然拦下、纠缠、逼问”的感觉。
常见搭配：**be accosted by**（被……拦住/纠缠）；对比：**approach**（中性：走近/接近）、**confront**（更强：当面对质）。

summary.en: Accoil is an archaic verb meaning “to coil or wind up.”
summary.zh: Accoil 是一个较古老的动词，意思是“盘绕、卷起”。

definition.en: (Archaic) to coil or wind up; to curl into a ring or spiral.
definition.zh: （古义）使盘绕；卷起；蜷成圈或螺旋状。

examples.en: In older texts, a serpent may be described as accoiling around a branch.
examples.zh: 在较早的文本里，蛇可能会被描写为盘绕在树枝上。

examples.en: The rope accoiled itself into a neat circle on the deck.
examples.zh: 绳子在甲板上卷成了整齐的一圈。

extraExplanation: “accoil”在现代英语中非常少见，多见于较早的文学或历史文本；现代更常用的词是“coil”（盘绕、卷起）。
词形上可以理解为“a-（使…处于某状态）+ coil（盘绕）”，但日常写作与口语里通常不建议用“accoil”，用“coil / curl / wind”会更自然。

summary.en: Accokeek is a community/place name in Maryland, USA.
summary.zh: Accokeek 是美国马里兰州的一个社区/地名。

definition.en: A place name: an unincorporated community and census-designated place in Prince George’s County, Maryland, in the United States, near the Potomac River.
definition.zh: 地名：美国马里兰州乔治王子县（Prince George’s County）的一处非建制社区与人口普查指定地区（CDP），靠近波托马克河（Potomac River）。

examples.en: Accokeek is located in southern Prince George’s County, Maryland.
examples.zh: Accokeek 位于马里兰州乔治王子县南部。

examples.en: They took a weekend walk on trails near the Potomac River in Accokeek.
examples.zh: 他们周末在 Accokeek 附近的波托马克河步道散步。

extraExplanation: “Accokeek”源自当地原住民语言（常被认为与Piscataway/Algonquian语系有关），通常被解释为与“河边/水边”相关的含义。作为地名，它在日常英语中一般不翻译，只保留原拼写。

summary.en: Accolade most commonly means an honor or award, or high praise for an achievement.
summary.zh: Accolade 最常指“荣誉/奖项”或“对成就的高度赞扬”。

definition.en: an award, honor, or strong praise given to someone for an achievement
definition.zh: （因成就而获得的）奖项、荣誉；高度赞扬

examples.en: The film received several accolades at international festivals.
examples.zh: 这部电影在国际电影节上获得了多项荣誉。

examples.en: She earned accolades for her work in public health.
examples.zh: 她因在公共卫生领域的工作而赢得了高度赞扬。

definition.en: a touch or gesture showing approval or respect (historically, a ceremonial tap when making someone a knight)
definition.zh: 表示认可或尊敬的触碰/仪式动作（历史上指授予骑士时的仪式性轻拍）

examples.en: In medieval tradition, the accolade was part of the knighting ceremony.
examples.zh: 在中世纪传统中，“授勋轻拍”是封爵仪式的一部分。

extraExplanation: 词源与文化背景：accolade 来自法语，原意与“拥抱/搭肩的致意”有关，后来与骑士授勋仪式联系在一起（在肩上轻拍或拥抱以示授衔）。现代英语中最常用的意思是“荣誉/奖项/赞誉”。
使用提示：accolades 常用复数，表示“许多荣誉/奖项/好评”。常见搭配有 win/receive/earn accolades（赢得/获得/赢取赞誉）以及 critical accolades（评论界好评）。

summary.en: “Accoladed” means “honored or praised,” and it can also be the past form of the rare verb “accolade.”
summary.zh: “Accoladed”意为“受表彰/受称赞的”，也可作较少见动词“accolade”的过去式/过去分词。

definition.en: (Adj.) Honored or praised; having received an accolade (an award or special praise).
definition.zh: （形容词）受表彰的；受称赞的；获得荣誉/奖项的。

examples.en: The accoladed scientist gave a talk to inspire young researchers.
examples.zh: 这位获表彰的科学家做了一场演讲，激励年轻研究者。

examples.en: She became an accoladed author after winning a major literary prize.
examples.zh: 在获得重要文学奖项后，她成了一位备受称赞的作家。

definition.en: (V.) Past tense/past participle of the rare verb “to accolade”: to award an honor or express strong praise.
definition.zh: （动词）“accolade”的过去式/过去分词（较少见用法）：授予荣誉；给予高度赞扬。

examples.en: The committee accoladed him for his years of service.
examples.zh: 委员会表彰了他多年的服务。

examples.en: She was accoladed by her peers for her leadership.
examples.zh: 她因领导力而受到同侪称赞。

extraExplanation:
“accoladed”在现代英语里不算常见。更自然的表达通常是：
- “honored / praised / award-winning / celebrated”
- 或者用名词：“receive an accolade”=“获得表彰/荣誉”。

词源背景：accolade原指中世纪骑士授勋仪式中的轻拍肩颈动作，后来引申为“授勋、表彰、赞誉”。

summary.en: Accolades are public praise or honors for an achievement, often used in the plural; historically, it can also mean a knighting ceremony.
summary.zh: Accolades 指对成就的公开赞誉或荣誉（常用复数）；历史上也可指封骑士等授勋仪式。

definition.en: public praise, awards, or expressions of approval given for an achievement
definition.zh: （对成就的）公开称赞、荣誉、奖项；嘉奖

examples.en: The film received accolades from critics around the world.
examples.zh: 这部电影获得了全球影评人的高度赞誉。

examples.en: She earned accolades for her work in public health.
examples.zh: 她因在公共卫生领域的工作而赢得了荣誉与赞扬。

definition.en: (historical) a ceremonial act of honoring someone, especially knighting
definition.zh: （历史用法）授予荣誉的仪式性行为，尤指封爵/授予骑士爵位

examples.en: In medieval times, the accolade marked the moment a squire became a knight.
examples.zh: 在中世纪，“accolade”指侍从被册封为骑士的那一刻。

extraExplanation: “Accolades”常用复数形式，尤其在新闻、影评、简历中表示“各种荣誉/好评”。
词源与法语有关，原意含“拥抱/环抱”的动作，后来引申为授勋或授予荣誉的仪式（如轻触肩膀的封爵礼）。
搭配很常见：win/receive/earn accolades（赢得/获得/赢取赞誉），shower someone with accolades（对某人大加赞扬）。

summary.en: Accolated is a rare adjective meaning either “linked together under a brace/bracket” or “honored with an accolade.”
summary.zh: accolated 是个罕见的形容词，可指“用括号/大括号连在一起”，也可指“受到嘉奖/获得荣誉”。

definition.en: (Rare) Joined or linked together; shown as connected under one bracket or brace (often in music, printing, or heraldry).
definition.zh: （罕见）连接在一起的；（常见于乐谱、排版或纹章学）用一个大括号/花括号括起来表示相连的。

examples.en: In the score, the two violin parts are accolated under one brace.
examples.zh: 在乐谱中，两条小提琴声部用同一个大括号连在一起。

examples.en: The editor accolated the related items to show they belong together.
examples.zh: 编辑把相关条目用括号连起来，以表示它们属于同一组。

definition.en: (Rare) Honored with an accolade; awarded praise or a prize.
definition.zh: （罕见）受到嘉奖的；获得荣誉或奖项的。

examples.en: The film was accolated at several international festivals.
examples.zh: 这部电影在多个国际电影节上获奖并受到表彰。

examples.en: She is widely accolated for her work in education.
examples.zh: 她因在教育领域的工作而广受赞誉。

extraExplanation:
“accolated”非常少见，日常英语里更常用的是：
1) 名词/动词 “accolade”/“acclaim”（赞誉、奖项；称赞）；
2) 形容词更常见写法是 “acclaimed”（广受赞誉的）。
如果你本来想表达“获奖的/备受好评的”，多半应写 “acclaimed”。
如果你想表达“用括号连在一起”，在排版或乐谱语境里用 “braced/under a brace” 也更常见。

summary.en: Accolent is a rare adjective meaning “leaning against” or “growing closely attached,” often seen in older or botanical writing.
summary.zh: Accolent 是一个罕见形容词，意为“倚靠/贴附”或“紧贴生长”，常见于旧式或植物学语境。

definition.en: (Rare) leaning against; clinging or growing closely alongside something.
definition.zh: （罕见）倚靠着的；贴附的；（尤指植物）紧贴着某物生长的。

examples.en: In old botanical notes, an accolent vine is described as clinging closely to the tree trunk.
examples.zh: 在较早的植物学笔记里，“accolent”的藤本被描述为紧贴树干攀附生长。

examples.en: The ivy lay accolent against the stone wall.
examples.zh: 常春藤紧贴着石墙生长。

extraExplanation: 这个词非常少见，多出现在旧式英语或植物学描写中。日常英语里更常用的表达是：clinging (to), pressed against, leaning against, close-growing。
不要把它和 accolade（荣誉、赞誉）混淆：两者拼写相近，但意思完全不同。

summary.en: “accoll” is not a standard English word; it is likely a misspelling (often of “appall,” “accolade,” or “collar”).
summary.zh: “accoll” 不是标准英语单词；很可能是拼写错误（常见是 appall、accolade 或 collar）。

definition.en: Not a standard English word. It is likely a misspelling of another word (common possibilities: “appall,” “accolade,” or “collar,” depending on what you meant).
definition.zh: 不是标准英语单词。很可能是其他单词的拼写错误（常见可能：appall、accolade 或 collar，取决于你想表达的意思）。

examples.en: Did you mean “appall” (The news appalled me.)?
examples.zh: 你想写的是 “appall” 吗？（The news appalled me. 这条消息让我震惊/反感。）

examples.en: Did you mean “accolade” (She received an accolade for her work.)?
examples.zh: 你想写的是 “accolade” 吗？（She received an accolade for her work. 她因工作获得了嘉奖/赞誉。）

examples.en: Did you mean “collar” (He grabbed the dog by the collar.)?
examples.zh: 你想写的是 “collar” 吗？（He grabbed the dog by the collar. 他抓住狗的项圈。）

extraExplanation: “accoll” 在英语词典中通常找不到作为独立词条。如果你能告诉我它出现的句子/语境（例如一整句话、你想表达“称赞/震惊/项圈”等哪一类意思），我可以帮你锁定最可能的正确拼写与用法。

summary.en: Accolade most commonly means an honor or public praise; less commonly, it means a ceremonial embrace or touch.
summary.zh: Accolade 最常见指“表彰/荣誉/赞誉”；较少见指“仪式性的拥抱或触礼”。

definition.en: an award, honor, or public praise given to someone for an achievement
definition.zh: （对成就的）表彰；荣誉；赞誉

examples.en: The scientist received accolades for her groundbreaking research.
examples.zh: 这位科学家因其开创性的研究而获得了许多赞誉。

examples.en: He earned international accolades after winning the competition.
examples.zh: 他赢得比赛后获得了国际性的表彰。

definition.en: an embrace or ceremonial touch (an older, more formal meaning)
definition.zh: 拥抱；（仪式性的）搭肩/触碰（较旧、较正式的用法）

examples.en: In the old ceremony, the knight received an accolade from the king.
examples.zh: 在古老的仪式中，国王为骑士举行授勋触礼。

extraExplanation: “accolle”在现代英语里通常不是标准拼写；你可能想查的是 **accolade**（最常见）——意思是“表彰/荣誉/赞誉”。
词源提示：**accolade** 来自法语/拉丁语词根，和“拥抱、搭在脖子上”的动作有关，因此既可指“拥抱/授勋触礼”（旧义），也引申为“授予荣誉、赞扬”（常用义）。
相关用法：常见搭配是 **receive/earn/win accolades**（获得赞誉/表彰）。文学或历史语境里，**the accolade** 也常指“骑士授勋仪式中的触礼”。

summary.en: Accolade means an honor, award, or public praise for achievement; historically, it can mean a ceremony of conferring knighthood.
summary.zh: Accolade 指因成就而获得的荣誉、奖项或公开赞扬；历史上也可指授予骑士等荣誉的仪式。

definition.en: (Likely intended word) an award, honor, or public praise given to someone for an achievement.
definition.zh: （你可能想写的词）奖项；荣誉；（公开的）赞扬，用来表彰某人的成就。

examples.en: The scientist received many accolades for her research.
examples.zh: 这位科学家因她的研究获得了许多荣誉与赞扬。

examples.en: Her performance earned critical acclaim and several accolades.
examples.zh: 她的表演赢得了评论界的高度评价以及多个奖项。

definition.en: (Historical) a formal act of giving someone a high honor, such as making someone a knight.
definition.zh: （历史用法）授予崇高荣誉的正式仪式，例如册封某人为骑士。

examples.en: In medieval times, the accolade could mark the moment someone became a knight.
examples.zh: 在中世纪，“accolade”可指某人成为骑士的那个正式仪式。

extraExplanation: 你输入的“accolled”不是常见英文单词；最可能是拼写错误，正确词通常是 **accolade**。
常见搭配：**receive/win/earn accolades**（获得赞誉/奖项）；形容词搭配：**many/great accolades**（许多/极高的荣誉）。
词源提示：来自法语，原意与“拥抱/授勋仪式”相关，所以既可指“赞誉/奖项”，也可指“授勋仪式”（较少见）。

summary.en: Accolée means “joined side by side,” mainly used in heraldry to describe linked shields or emblems.
summary.zh: Accolée 指“并列相连”，主要用于纹章学中描述相接的盾徽或徽记。

definition.en: (Heraldry) Joined or placed side by side; said especially of shields, coats of arms, or other emblems that touch or are linked together.
definition.zh: （纹章学）并列相连的；尤指盾徽、纹章或徽记彼此相接或相连摆放。

examples.en: The two shields are shown accolée to represent the union of the families.
examples.zh: 图中两面盾徽以 accolée（并列相连）的方式呈现，用来象征两大家族的结合。

examples.en: In the book’s illustration, the emblems appear accolée beneath a single crown.
examples.zh: 在书中的插图里，徽记被画成 accolée（并列相连），并置于同一顶王冠之下。

extraExplanation: “accolée”（也写作 accolee 或 accolé/accolée）源自法语，来自动词 accoler，意为“贴在一起、使相接”。在英语里它主要出现在纹章学（heraldry）与相关艺术史/设计描述中，日常会话很少用。
不要把它和常见词 “accolade”（嘉奖、赞誉）混淆：accolée 讲的是“图像/徽章的并置相连”，accolade 讲的是“荣誉/称赞”。
阅读纹章或家族史资料时，你可能会看到类似表达：“shields accolée”（并列相接的盾徽），常用来表示联姻、联盟或合并。

summary.en: Accomac is a town on Virginia’s Eastern Shore; it’s also a common spelling variant related to “Accomack.”
summary.zh: Accomac 是美国弗吉尼亚州东海岸的一座小镇；也常被视为与 “Accomack” 相关的拼写变体。

definition.en: A small town in Accomack County on Virginia’s Eastern Shore (USA).
definition.zh: 美国弗吉尼亚州东海岸（Eastern Shore）阿科马克县的一座小镇。

examples.en: She grew up in Accomac on Virginia’s Eastern Shore.
examples.zh: 她在弗吉尼亚州东海岸的 Accomac 长大。

examples.en: The county offices are located in Accomac.
examples.zh: 县政府办公机构设在 Accomac。

definition.en: A spelling variant of “Accomack,” used especially in place names (e.g., Accomac town vs. Accomack County).
definition.zh: “Accomack”的一种拼写变体，常见于地名用法（如 Accomac 镇与 Accomack 县）。

examples.en: Don’t confuse Accomac (the town) with Accomack (the county).
examples.zh: 不要把 Accomac（镇）和 Accomack（县）弄混。

synonyms: Accomack (variant spelling, in related place names)
extraExplanation: “Accomac/Accomack”一词与当地原住民语言有关，历史上用于指代弗吉尼亚东海岸一带的原住民群体与地名。现代英语里多作为专有名词使用（地名、县名），日常写作通常需要首字母大写。

summary.en: Accomack is a place name in Virginia, best known as Accomack County on the Eastern Shore.
summary.zh: Accomack 是弗吉尼亚州的地名，最常指东岸地区的阿科马克县（Accomack County）。

definition.en: a county on the Eastern Shore of Virginia, USA (Accomack County).
definition.zh: 美国弗吉尼亚州东岸地区的一个县（阿科马克县，Accomack County）。

examples.en: She grew up in Accomack County on Virginia’s Eastern Shore.
examples.zh: 她在弗吉尼亚州东岸的阿科马克县长大。

examples.en: Accomack is known for small towns, farms, and coastal life.
examples.zh: 阿科马克以小镇、农场和海岸生活而闻名。

definition.en: a place name used for local communities in Virginia, such as the community of Accomack.
definition.zh: 弗吉尼亚州的一些社区地名用法，例如名为 Accomack 的社区。

examples.en: We stopped for lunch in Accomack on our way up the peninsula.
examples.zh: 我们在沿半岛北上时在 Accomack 停下来吃了午饭。

extraExplanation: “Accomack”是一个源自美洲原住民语言的地名（常被解释为与“在水对岸/在水边”之类的含义有关）。在美国英语里，它主要作为专有名词使用，通常不翻译含义，只音译或直接保留原拼写。
在新闻、地图、地址中常见搭配：Accomack County（阿科马克县）、Accomack, Virginia（弗州阿科马克）。

summary.en: Accommodation most commonly means a place to stay; it can also mean arrangements to meet needs, adaptation, or a compromise.
summary.zh: Accommodation 最常见意思是“住宿/住处”；也可指“便利安排、适应调整或（观点分歧间的）妥协”。

definition.en: a place to live or stay, especially for a short time (a hotel, room, apartment, etc.)
definition.zh: 住宿；住处（尤指短期住宿，如酒店、房间、公寓等）

examples.en: We need to book accommodation for two nights.
examples.zh: 我们需要预订两晚的住宿。

examples.en: This accommodation is close to the subway.
examples.zh: 这个住处离地铁很近。

definition.en: the process of providing help or space for someone; making arrangements to meet someone’s needs
definition.zh: 照顾与安排；提供便利（满足他人需要的安排）

examples.en: The school made an accommodation for students with disabilities.
examples.zh: 学校为残障学生提供了便利安排。

examples.en: Thank you for your accommodation during my visit.
examples.zh: 感谢你在我来访期间的周到安排。

definition.en: a change or adjustment to fit a new situation; adaptation
definition.zh: 适应；调整（为适合新情况而改变）

examples.en: Moving abroad requires accommodation to a new culture.
examples.zh: 搬到国外需要适应新的文化。

definition.en: an agreement or compromise between people with different views
definition.zh: 和解；妥协（在不同观点之间达成的协议）

examples.en: They reached an accommodation after weeks of talks.
examples.zh: 经过数周谈判，他们达成了妥协。

extraExplanation: “accombination”不是常见英文单词。最可能的拼写目标是 **accommodation**（住宿/便利安排/适应/妥协）。也有人会把它和 **combination**（组合）混淆：combination 指“把东西组合在一起”，而 accommodation 更偏“提供住处/照顾安排/适应”。

summary.en: Accommodable means “able to be accommodated,” and more rarely “willing to adapt or agree.”
summary.zh: accommodable 指“可被容纳/可被安排的”，更少见时也可指“随和、愿意配合的”。

definition.en: Able to be accommodated (fit in; arranged for; provided with what is needed).
definition.zh: 可被容纳的；可被安置/安排的；能满足需要的。

examples.en: The conference room is accommodable for about 30 people.
examples.zh: 这个会议室大约能容纳30个人。

examples.en: Your schedule is accommodable if we move the meeting to Friday.
examples.zh: 如果我们把会议改到周五，你的时间安排就能配合得上。

definition.en: (Rare) Willing to adapt or agree; easy to work with; compliant.
definition.zh: （罕见）随和的；愿意迁就/配合的；好商量的。

examples.en: He was accommodable and accepted the changes without complaint.
examples.zh: 他很随和，毫无怨言地接受了这些改动。

examples.en: Try to be accommodable when plans change unexpectedly.
examples.zh: 计划突然变化时，尽量保持好商量、愿意配合。

extraExplanation: “accommodable”在现代英语里非常少见，日常更常用“accommodating”（乐于助人的、愿意迁就的）或“adaptable/flexible”（适应力强的、灵活的）。如果你想表达“能容纳/能安排”，更自然的说法常是“can accommodate … / is able to accommodate …”。

summary.en: Accommodableness means a cooperative, flexible willingness to adjust and help others.
summary.zh: Accommodableness 指通融随和、愿意配合并为他人调整与提供便利的品质。

definition.en: the quality of being willing and able to adjust, help, or make things easier for others; a flexible, cooperative nature
definition.zh: （性格或态度上的）通融、随和、乐于配合；愿意并能够为了他人调整或提供便利的品质

examples.en: Her accommodableness made it easy for the team to agree on a plan.
examples.zh: 她的通融随和让团队很容易就达成了计划共识。

examples.en: We appreciated his accommodableness when the schedule changed at the last minute.
examples.zh: 行程临时改变时，我们很感激他愿意配合、很通融。

examples.en: In customer service, accommodableness can turn a complaint into a positive experience.
examples.zh: 在客服工作中，通融与配合往往能把投诉变成一次正面体验。

extraExplanation: “accommodableness”在现代英语里比较少见，更常用的名词是“accommodating nature”（随和的性格）或“accommodativeness”。它来自形容词“accommodable”（可通融的、可调适的）以及动词“accommodate”（提供便利；使适应）。
注意区分：这里的“accommodableness”强调人的“通融/配合”，不是“住宿”（accommodations）。

summary.en: “Accommodatable” means “able to be accommodated”—able to fit, be arranged, or have needs met.
summary.zh: “accommodatable”表示“可被安排/容纳/满足需求的”，即事情或需求是“可以被照顾到、可以协调解决的”。

definition.en: Able to be accommodated; able to fit, be provided for, or be arranged without too much difficulty.
definition.zh: 可被容纳的；可被安置/安排的；能适应的（通常指能被满足需求或能放得下）。

examples.en: Up to 200 guests are accommodatable in the main hall.
examples.zh: 主厅最多可容纳200位宾客。

examples.en: Most dietary restrictions are accommodatable with advance notice.
examples.zh: 大多数饮食限制如果提前告知都可以安排满足。

examples.en: Your request is accommodatable, but we need two more days.
examples.zh: 你的请求可以安排，但我们需要再多两天。

extraExplanation: “accommodatable”在日常英语中不算常见，写作或正式通知里偶尔会出现。更常见、也更自然的表达有：“can be accommodated”“is feasible”“is manageable”“we can make arrangements”。
拼写提示：accommodate 这个词中间是双 c、双 m（ac-co-mmo-date）。很多人会把 c 或 m 少写一个。
相关变体：你可能也会看到“accommodable”（更短的形容词形式），但同样偏正式、使用频率不高。

summary.en: Accommodate means to provide space or lodging, or to adjust/helpfully meet someone’s needs or requests.
summary.zh: Accommodate 常指“容纳/提供住宿”，也可指“调整以适应、配合需求”或“通融满足请求”。

definition.en: to provide someone with a place to stay or enough space; to house or seat
definition.zh: 为（某人）提供住宿或足够空间；容纳

examples.en: The hotel can accommodate up to 300 guests.
examples.zh: 这家酒店最多可容纳300位客人。

examples.en: The bus can’t accommodate any more passengers.
examples.zh: 这辆公交车不能再容纳更多乘客了。

definition.en: to adjust or change to fit a situation, a need, or a person; to make room for
definition.zh: 调整以适应（情况/需求/他人）；为……腾出空间、作出让步

examples.en: We can accommodate your schedule by meeting earlier.
examples.zh: 我们可以配合你的时间，把会议安排得更早。

examples.en: The company accommodated employees with flexible hours.
examples.zh: 公司为员工提供了弹性工作时间以方便他们。

definition.en: to do a favor for someone; to be helpful by meeting their request
definition.zh: 帮忙满足请求；通融、照顾（他人）

examples.en: Could you accommodate me and hold the package until tomorrow?
examples.zh: 你能通融一下，把包裹替我留到明天吗？

examples.en: Thank you for accommodating our last-minute change.
examples.zh: 谢谢你们配合我们临时的变更。

extraExplanation: 常见搭配：accommodate someone with something（为某人提供某物，如“accommodate guests with free breakfast”）；accommodate to/for（较少见或更正式，表示“适应/顾及”）。在商务英语里，accommodate 常带有“尽量配合、满足要求”的礼貌语气。
词源提示：来自拉丁语，核心含义是“使合适、使有空间”，因此既能表示“容纳”，也能表示“调整以适应”。

word: accommodate member countries at different levels of development

summary.en: to make rules or plans flexible enough to meet different needs
summary.zh: 使规则或安排足够灵活，以满足不同需求

definition.en: to take into account and meet the different needs or conditions of member countries that are at different stages of development
definition.zh: 考虑并满足发展水平不同的成员国的不同需求或条件

examples.en: The agreement is designed to accommodate member countries at different levels of development.
examples.zh: 该协议旨在兼顾发展水平不同的成员国。

examples.en: The policy includes flexible timelines to accommodate member countries at different levels of development.
examples.zh: 该政策包含灵活的时间表，以便照顾到发展程度不同的成员国。

examples.en: Funding rules were adjusted to accommodate member countries at different levels of development.
examples.zh: 资金规则作出调整，以适应发展水平不同的成员国。

extraExplanation: 常见于国际组织/条约语境：这里的 accommodate 更接近“兼顾、照顾到、允许差异”，强调规则要有弹性（例如差别待遇、分阶段目标、灵活期限）。
表达上更正式的同类说法：take into account / allow for / cater to / be flexible enough to accommodate …。
etymology: accommodate 源自拉丁语 *commodus*（“合适的、方便的”），加前缀 *ac-*（强调/趋向）形成“使之合适、提供便利”的含义；后来引申为“照顾、满足（不同需求）”。
mnemonic: 把 accommodate 拆开记：ac-（加强）+ commod（方便/合适，联想“commodity 商品=让交易更便利”）→“让事情更合适/更方便”→“照顾到需求”。
联想中文：accommodate ≈ “给你安排得妥妥的”（安排=让对方方便、合适）。

summary.en: provide enough space or adjust arrangements so additional people can be included
summary.zh: 提供足够空间或调整安排以便让更多人被容纳/参与

definition.en: to provide enough space, seats, or lodging for a larger number of people
definition.zh: 容纳更多人；为更多人提供空间/座位/住宿

examples.en: The hall can accommodate more people if we remove the extra tables.
examples.zh: 如果我们把多余的桌子撤掉，这个大厅就能容纳更多人。

examples.en: We need a bigger bus to accommodate more people.
examples.zh: 我们需要一辆更大的巴士来容纳更多人。

definition.en: to adjust plans, rules, or arrangements so that additional people can be included
definition.zh: 调整安排/规则以便让更多人参与或被照顾到

examples.en: The teacher extended the deadline to accommodate more people who were sick.
examples.zh: 老师延长了截止日期，以便照顾到更多生病的同学。

examples.en: They changed the meeting time to accommodate more people in different time zones.
examples.zh: 他们调整了会议时间，以便让不同时区的更多人都能参加。

extraExplanation: 常见搭配：accommodate more people / accommodate additional guests（容纳更多人/更多客人）；accommodate someone’s needs/schedule（照顾某人的需求/时间安排）。
在英语里，accommodate 不只是“住宿”，也常表示“为了让更多人方便而调整安排”，在工作与学校场景非常高频。
etymology: “accommodate”源自拉丁语 accommodare，意为“使合适、使便利”（ad- 表“向、使” + commodus 表“合适的、方便的”）。后来引申出“提供住处/空间”“做出调整以满足需要”等常见含义。
mnemonic: 联想中文“住宿/容纳”：accommodate 听起来像“啊靠莫得（位子）”→ 需要“安排位子/空间”来容纳更多人。
拆分记：ac- + commod（像 commodity 的 commod-，联想“资源/便利”）→ 让资源与安排变得更便利，能装下更多人。

summary.en: provide space or adjust arrangements to meet people’s needs
summary.zh: 为人们提供容纳/接待或调整安排以满足需求

definition.en: to provide space, services, or arrangements for people so they can stay, work, or take part comfortably
definition.zh: 为人们提供住宿、空间、服务或安排，使其能舒适地停留、工作或参与

examples.en: The hotel can accommodate 200 people during the conference.
examples.zh: 这家酒店在会议期间可以接待200人。

examples.en: We’ll accommodate people with disabilities by providing ramps and reserved seating.
examples.zh: 我们将通过提供坡道和预留座位来照顾残障人士的需求。

examples.en: The organizer accommodated people who arrived late by saving a few seats.
examples.zh: 组织者为迟到的人留了几个座位，方便他们参加。

definition.en: to adjust plans or rules to meet people’s needs or preferences
definition.zh: 调整计划或规则以满足人们的需求或偏好

examples.en: The teacher tried to accommodate people with different learning styles.
examples.zh: 老师尽量照顾不同学习风格的学生。

examples.en: We can accommodate people who don’t eat meat with vegetarian options.
examples.zh: 我们可以为不吃肉的人准备素食选项。

extraExplanation: 常见搭配：accommodate people with + 名词（为……人群提供……）：accommodate people with allergies（照顾过敏人群）。
在正式场合（酒店、交通、活动管理）里，accommodate 常指“接待/容纳”；在工作学习场景里常指“照顾到、迁就、调整安排”。
etymology: 源自拉丁语前缀 ad-（朝向）+ accommodare（使合适、安置），经法语进入英语。核心含义从“使……合适”发展到“为……提供便利/安排”。
mnemonic: 把 accommodate 拆开记：ac-（使）+ commod-（方便/舒适，联想“commodities 商品/便利”）→“让人方便、住得舒服”。
联想中文“安排妥当”：accommodate people = 把人“安顿好/安排好”。

summary.en: adjust something to fit a need or situation
summary.zh: 调整某物以适应需要或情况

definition.en: to change or adjust something so it fits a new purpose, situation, rule, or need
definition.zh: 把某物调整/改造到适合某种用途、情况、规则或需要

examples.en: The design was modified to accommodate the new safety rules.
examples.zh: 这个设计被修改，以适应新的安全规定。

examples.en: Schools should accommodate teaching materials to different learning styles.
examples.zh: 学校应把教学材料调整到适合不同的学习方式。

examples.en: We accommodated the schedule to her time zone.
examples.zh: 我们把日程调整到适合她的时区。

definition.en: to consider and accept another person’s needs or wishes when making plans
definition.zh: 在安排时照顾并接受他人的需求或意愿

examples.en: We tried to accommodate our plans to what everyone could afford.
examples.zh: 我们尽量把计划调整到大家都负担得起。

examples.en: The host accommodated the menu to the guest’s allergies.
examples.zh: 主人把菜单调整到适合客人的过敏情况。

extraExplanation: 常见结构是“accommodate A to B”：把A调整到适合B（更正式、书面一些）。例如：accommodate the policy to reality（让政策贴合现实）。
不要和“accommodate + 人（提供住宿/容纳）”混淆：accommodate guests = 为客人提供住宿/接待；而这里强调“调整以适应”。
也可见“accommodate yourself to …”（使自己适应……），但“adapt (yourself) to …”在口语中更常用。
etymology: 源自拉丁语 accommodare（使……合适、调整），由 ad-（朝向）+ commodus（合适的、方便的）构成；后来在英语中发展出“使适应/迁就”的常见用法。
mnemonic: 把它拆开记：ac- + commodate ≈ “让……更方便/更合适（commod-像common/comfortable的感觉）”。
联想中文：把东西“安排到位”= 调整到合适的位置/状态。

word: accommodate the actual conditions of all parties concerned

summary.en: adjust to fit everyone’s real situation
summary.zh: 根据各方实际情况作出调整以兼顾各方

definition.en: to adjust plans, rules, or arrangements so they fit the real situation and meet (as much as possible) the needs of everyone involved
definition.zh: 根据各方的实际情况来调整安排/规则，尽量兼顾相关各方的需要

examples.en: The policy was revised to accommodate the actual conditions of all parties concerned.
examples.zh: 该政策已作修订，以兼顾相关各方的实际情况。

examples.en: We need a timeline that accommodates the actual conditions of all parties concerned, not just the ideal schedule.
examples.zh: 我们需要一个能兼顾相关各方实际情况的时间表，而不是只按理想进度来定。

examples.en: The mediator proposed a compromise that would accommodate the actual conditions of all parties concerned.
examples.zh: 调解员提出了一个折中方案，以兼顾相关各方的实际情况。

phonetic: /əˈkɑməˌdeɪt ði ˈæk.tʃu.əl kənˈdɪʃənz əv ɔl ˈpɑr.tiz kənˈsɝnd/
extraExplanation: all parties concerned 表示“所有相关方/有关各方”，常见于合同、政策、通知等正式语境。
accommodate 在这里不是“住宿”，而是“调整/照顾到/兼顾”。可替换理解为“make something fit the real situation”。
etymology: accommodate 源自拉丁语 accommodare，原意是“使合适、使适应”（ad- “向、使” + commodus “合适、方便”）。在现代英语里常用于“调整以适应情况/需求”，也可表示“为……提供便利或住宿”。
mnemonic: 把 accommodate 记成“a + common + date”：让大家有共同的安排（date/计划），彼此都能配合＝兼顾各方。
联想中文“调适”：accommodate = 调整使其适合（适应实际情况）。

word: accommodate the interests of all parties

summary.en: balance and satisfy everyone’s needs or concerns through adjustment or compromise
summary.zh: 通过调整或妥协来平衡并满足各方诉求

definition.en: to take everyone’s needs or concerns into account and try to satisfy them fairly, often by making adjustments or compromises
definition.zh: 兼顾各方利益（考虑所有人的需求/关切，并通过调整或妥协尽量让各方都满意）

examples.en: The agreement was designed to accommodate the interests of all parties.
examples.zh: 这份协议旨在兼顾各方利益。

examples.en: We adjusted the schedule to accommodate the interests of all parties involved.
examples.zh: 我们调整了日程安排，以兼顾所有相关方的利益。

examples.en: It’s hard to accommodate the interests of all parties when time and money are limited.
examples.zh: 当时间和资金有限时，很难兼顾各方利益。

extraExplanation: all parties 指“所有当事方/相关方”，常见于商务谈判、合同、法律或正式协商语境。
accommodate 在正式语境里常译作“兼顾/照顾/满足”；但在其他语境也可指“提供住宿/容纳”（accommodate guests）。这里是“照顾各方利益”的意思。
interests 在这里多指“利益、诉求、关切点”，不只是“兴趣爱好”。
etymology: accommodate 来自拉丁语 accommodare，含义是“使……合适、调适、安排妥当”。在现代英语里常用于“满足需要/迁就/为……提供便利”，搭配 interests/needs/requests 很常见。
mnemonic: 把 accommodate 记成“a + common + date（共同定个日子/方案）”：为了让大家都合适，就要一起协调、调整。
联想“调配/调和”：accommodate = 把条件‘调到合适’，从而‘兼顾’各方。

summary.en: adjust to something, provide space, or meet someone’s needs
summary.zh: 适应；容纳；迁就/满足需求

definition.en: (Commonly in the form “accommodate oneself to…”) to adjust or adapt to a new situation, rule, or environment.
definition.zh: （常用“accommodate oneself to…”）使自己适应新的情况、规则或环境。

examples.en: It took me a few weeks to accommodate myself to the new schedule.
examples.zh: 我花了几个星期才让自己适应新的作息。

examples.en: Students must accommodate themselves to the school’s rules.
examples.zh: 学生必须让自己适应学校的规定。

definition.en: to provide enough space for someone or something; to fit or hold.
definition.zh: 为……提供足够空间；容纳。

examples.en: This room can accommodate up to four people.
examples.zh: 这间房最多能容纳四个人。

examples.en: The bag is designed to accommodate a laptop.
examples.zh: 这个包的设计可以放下笔记本电脑。

definition.en: to help someone by doing what they want; to be willing to meet someone’s needs.
definition.zh: 迁就；照顾（他人需求）；答应帮忙。

examples.en: The store tried to accommodate customers with late opening hours.
examples.zh: 这家店尽量用延长营业时间来照顾顾客。

examples.en: Could you accommodate me by moving the meeting to Friday?
examples.zh: 你能帮我个忙，把会议改到周五吗？

extraExplanation: “accommodate to”本身不算最标准、最常见的搭配。英语里更自然的是：
1) adapt/adjust to + 名词：adapt to the new job（适应新工作）
2) accommodate oneself to + 名词：accommodate oneself to the new job（让自己适应）
3) accommodate + 人/需求：accommodate customers / accommodate your request（照顾顾客/满足请求）
口语或非正式写作里偶尔会见到“accommodate to…”，但在考试、正式写作中建议用上面更地道的结构。
etymology: 源自拉丁语 *accommodare*，由 *ad-*（向、到）+ *commodus*（合适的、方便的）构成，原意接近“使之合适、使之便利”，后来引申为“容纳、提供便利、迁就”，以及“（使自己）适应”。
mnemonic: 记“ac- + commod(方便/合适) + -ate(动词)”→“让事情变得合适/方便”→引申到“容纳、迁就、适应”。
联想中文“方便(commodus)别人”→ accommodate（照顾/迁就别人的需要）。

summary.en: “Accommodated” means provided lodging or adjusted/allowed something to meet someone’s needs.
summary.zh: “accommodated”常指“安排住宿”或“为满足需要而调整/通融（迁就）”。

definition.en: To provide someone with a place to live or stay; to give lodging.
definition.zh: 为某人提供住处；安排住宿。

examples.en: The hotel accommodated our family for three nights.
examples.zh: 那家酒店为我们家安排了三晚住宿。

examples.en: The university accommodated visiting scholars in on-campus housing.
examples.zh: 大学把来访学者安排在校内住房里。

definition.en: To adjust or change something to meet someone’s needs; to make an allowance for a situation.
definition.zh: 为满足需要而调整；通融；照顾到某种情况。

examples.en: The teacher accommodated students who needed extra time on the test.
examples.zh: 老师为需要更多考试时间的学生作了调整。

examples.en: The schedule was accommodated to fit everyone’s availability.
examples.zh: 时间表作了调整，以配合大家的空档。

definition.en: To do someone a favor by accepting their request, even if it is not ideal for you.
definition.zh: （不太情愿但仍）答应对方的要求；迁就。

examples.en: We accommodated her request to meet later, even though we were tired.
examples.zh: 尽管我们很累，还是迁就她把见面时间推迟了。

extraExplanation: “Accommodated”是动词“accommodate”的过去式/过去分词。常见搭配：accommodate someone (with sth)、accommodate a request、accommodate changes、be accommodated (in/at …)。
在职场与学校语境里，accommodate 常带有“合理便利/必要调整”的含义，比如为残障人士或有特殊需要者提供“accommodations（便利措施）”。

summary.en: “Accommodately” means “in a helpful, accommodating way.” It is uncommon in everyday English.
summary.zh: “accommodately”意为“以通融、乐于配合的方式”。日常英语中较少用。

definition.en: In an accommodating or helpful way; with a willingness to adjust to other people’s needs.
definition.zh: 以通融、乐于助人的方式；愿意为他人需求作出调整。

examples.en: She responded accommodately and offered to change the meeting time.
examples.zh: 她很通融地回应，并提出可以改会议时间。

examples.en: The hotel staff dealt accommodately with our late arrival.
examples.zh: 酒店员工对我们深夜到达很通融地处理。

extraExplanation: “Accommodately”在现代英语中较少见；更常用的说法是用短语表达同样意思，例如：in an accommodating way / accommodatingly / helpfully / flexibly。
词源上与动词 accommodate（“容纳；使适应；给……提供便利”）同源；这里的核心语感是“为别人让一步、提供便利”。

summary.en: Accommodateness means a helpful, flexible willingness to adjust to others’ needs.
summary.zh: Accommodateness 指乐于助人、愿意通融并根据他人需要作出调整的品质。

definition.en: the quality of being willing to help or adjust to other people’s needs; helpfulness and flexibility
definition.zh: 乐于配合、愿意帮助并根据他人需要作出调整的品质；通融与灵活

examples.en: Her accommodateness made it easy for the team to agree on a plan.
examples.zh: 她的通融与配合让团队很容易就达成了计划。

examples.en: We appreciated the staff’s accommodateness when our flight was delayed.
examples.zh: 航班延误时，我们很感谢工作人员的体贴与配合。

examples.en: In customer service, accommodateness can matter as much as speed.
examples.zh: 在客户服务中，愿意配合的重要性可能不亚于效率。

extraExplanation: “accommodateness”在现代英语里比较少见，更常用的表达是“accommodating nature / willingness to accommodate / helpfulness / flexibility”。写作中如果想更自然，通常会改用这些更常见的说法。
它来自形容词“accommodating”（乐于助人、愿意通融），加名词后缀“-ness”表示“……的性质/状态”。

summary.en: “Accommodates” means “provides space/lodging for” or “adjusts to meet a need.”
summary.zh: “accommodates”表示“提供住宿/容纳”或“调整以满足需要、予以通融”。

definition.en: to provide someone with a place to stay (housing/lodging), or to provide space for something
definition.zh: 为某人提供住宿；或为某物提供空间、容纳

examples.en: The hotel accommodates up to 300 guests.
examples.zh: 这家酒店最多可容纳300位客人。

examples.en: The dormitory accommodates international students during the summer program.
examples.zh: 暑期项目期间，这栋宿舍为国际学生提供住宿。

definition.en: to adjust or change something to fit a need or situation; to make an allowance for someone
definition.zh: 调整以适应需要或情况；对某人作出通融/照顾

examples.en: The schedule accommodates parents who work late.
examples.zh: 这个时间表照顾到下班晚的家长。

examples.en: We can accommodate your request if you tell us in advance.
examples.zh: 如果你提前告知，我们可以满足/配合你的要求。

extraExplanation: “Accommodates”是动词“accommodate”的第三人称单数形式（he/she/it accommodates）。常见搭配：accommodate guests（接待客人）、accommodate students（安置学生）、accommodate a request（满足要求）、accommodate changes（适应变化）。
语气上，“accommodate”比“help”更正式，常用于酒店、学校、公司政策、服务安排等场景。

summary.en: Accommodating describes a helpful, flexible person or something that suits needs or has enough space.
summary.zh: accommodating 常形容人很体贴、好配合，也可形容场所/安排能满足需求或容纳足够的人/物。

definition.en: Willing to help or adjust to other people’s needs; easy to work with.
definition.zh: 乐于助人、愿意迁就他人需求的；好相处的。

examples.en: Our host was very accommodating and changed the dinner time for us.
examples.zh: 我们的主人非常体贴，特意为我们调整了晚餐时间。

examples.en: She’s accommodating with her schedule, so meetings are easy to arrange.
